node.id: Based on the narrative, Miss Eyre has not yet experienced feelings of love and jealousy. She is described as having a "soul that sleeps" and has not undergone the "shock" that would awaken such emotions. She is still young and inexperienced, and the narrator, Mr. Rochester, notes that she has yet to feel love and therefore has not experienced jealousy either. Miss Eyre herself acknowledges that she has not felt these emotions when she asks Mr. Rochester how he knows that she has not experienced love or jealousy.

opera inamorata) alighted: though muffed in a cloak--an unnecessary encumbrance, by-the-bye, on so warm a June evening--I knew her instantly by her little foot, seen peeping from the skirt of her dress, as she skipped from the carriage-step. Bending over the balcony, I was about to murmur 'Mon ange'--in a tone, of course, which should be audible to the ear of love alone--when a figure jumped from the carriage after her; cloaked also; but that was a spurred heel which had rung on the pavement, and that was a hatted head which now passed under the arched _porte cochere_ of the hotel.
"You never felt jealousy, did you, Miss Eyre? Of course not: I need not ask you; because you never felt love. You have both sentiments yet to experience: your soul sleeps; the shock is yet to be given which shall waken it. You think all existence lapses in as quiet a flow as that in which your youth has hitherto slid away. Floating on with

not the less comforting and encouraging because it is very unobtrusive in its manifestations."
"How do you know?--how can you guess all this, sir?"
"I know it well; therefore I proceed almost as freely as if I were writing my thoughts in a diary. You would say, I should have been superior to circumstances; so I should--so I should; but you see I was not. When fate wronged me, I had not the wisdom to remain cool: I turned desperate; then I degenerated. Now, when any vicious simpleton excites my disgust by his paltry ribaldry, I cannot flatter myself that I am better than he: I am forced to confess that he and I are on a level. I wish I had stood firm--God knows I do! Dread remorse when you are tempted to err, Miss Eyre; remorse is the poison of life."
"Repentance is said to be its cure, sir."
"It is not its cure. Reformation may be its cure; and I could reform--I have strength yet for that--if--but

damask-covered chair, looked different to what I had seen him look before; not quite so stern--much less gloomy. There was a smile on his lips, and his eyes sparkled, whether with wine or not, I am not sure; but I think it very probable. He was, in short, in his after-dinner mood; more expanded and genial, and also more self- indulgent than the frigid and rigid temper of the morning; still he looked preciously grim, cushioning his massive head against the swelling back of his chair, and receiving the light of the fire on his granite- hewn features, and in his great, dark eyes; for he had great, dark eyes, and very fine eyes, too--not without a certain change in their depths sometimes, which, if it was not softness, reminded you, at least, of that feeling.
He had been looking two minutes at the fire, and I had been looking the same length of time at him, when, turning suddenly, he caught my gaze fastened on his physiognomy.
"You examine me, Miss Eyre," said he:

old as you, I was a feeling fellow enough, partial to the unfledged, unfostered, and unlucky; but Fortune has knocked me about since: she has even kneaded me with her knuckles, and now I flatter myself I am hard and tough as an India-rubber ball; pervious, though, through a chink or two still, and with one sentient point in the middle of the lump. Yes: does that leave hope for me?"
"Hope of what, sir?"
"Of my final re-transformation from India-rubber back to flesh?"

I leave both the choice of subject and the manner of treating it entirely to yourself."
Accordingly I sat and said nothing: "If he expects me to talk for the mere sake of talking and showing off, he will find he has addressed himself to the wrong person," I thought.
"You are dumb, Miss Eyre."
I was dumb still. He bent his head a little towards me, and with a single hasty glance seemed to dive into my eyes.
"Stubborn?" he said, "and annoyed. Ah! it is consistent. I put my request in an absurd, almost insolent form. Miss Eyre, I beg your pardon. The fact is, once for all, I don't wish to treat you like an inferior: that is" (correcting himself), "I claim only such superiority as must result from twenty years' difference in age and a century's advance in experience. "It has struck nine, sir."

She pulled out of her box, about ten minutes ago, a little pink silk frock; rapture lit her face as she unfolded it; coquetry runs in her blood, blends with her brains, and seasons the marrow of her bones. The speaker advises against giving in to temptation, warning that it may lead to degeneration and further sin. He emphasizes the potential misery and bitterness that can result from yielding to temptation, stating, "It will sting--it will taste bitter, sir." The speaker also warns of the danger of remorse, describing it as the "poison of life."
On the other hand, the speaker encourages resisting temptation and choosing the path of reformation, stating that he has the strength to do so "if...hampered, burdened, cursed as I am." However, he expresses doubt about the possibility of reformation in his own situation, given his current circumstances.
The speaker also warns against underestimating the consequences of giving in to temptation, cautioning that the person tempted may not fully understand the potential outcomes. He tells the listener, "You have no right to preach to me, you neophyte, that have not passed the porch of life, and are absolutely unacquainted with its mysteries."
Overall, the speaker's advice is to resist temptation and choose the path of reformation, while also warning of the potential misery and bitterness that can result from giving in to temptation.

you neophyte, that have not passed the porch of life, and are absolutely unacquainted with its mysteries."
"I only remind you of your own words, sir: you said error brought remorse, and you pronounced remorse the poison of existence."
"And who talks of error now? I scarcely think the notion that flittered across my brain was an error. I believe it was an inspiration rather than a temptation: it was very genial, very soothing--I know that. Here it comes again! It is no devil, I assure you; or if it be, it has put on the robes of an angel of light. I think I must admit so fair a guest when it asks entrance to my heart."
"Distrust it, sir; it is not a true angel."
"Once more, how do you know? By what instinct do you pretend to distinguish between a fallen seraph of the abyss and a messenger from the eternal throne--between a guide and a seducer?"
"I judged by your countenance, sir, which was troubled when you said the suggestion had returned upon you.

"It is not its cure. Reformation may be its cure; and I could reform--I have strength yet for that--if--but where is the use of thinking of it, hampered, burdened, cursed as I am? Besides, since happiness is irrevocably denied me, I have a right to get pleasure out of life: and I _will_ get it, cost what it may."
"Then you will degenerate still more, sir."
"Possibly: yet why should I, if I can get sweet, fresh pleasure? And I may get it as sweet and fresh as the wild honey the bee gathers on the moor."
"It will sting--it will taste bitter, sir."
"How do you know?--you never tried it. How very serious--how very solemn you look: and you are as ignorant of the matter as this cameo head" (taking one from the mantelpiece). "Not at all--it bears the most gracious message in the world: for the rest, you are not my conscience-keeper, so don't make yourself uneasy. Here, come in, bonny wanderer!"

dawned I was tossed on a buoyant but unquiet sea, where billows of trouble rolled under surges of joy. I thought sometimes I saw beyond its wild waters a shore, sweet as the hills of Beulah; and now and then a freshening gale, wakened by hope, bore my spirit triumphantly towards the bourne: but I could not reach it, even in fancy--a counteracting breeze blew off land, and continually drove me back. Sense would resist delirium: judgment would warn passion. Too feverish to rest, I rose as soon as day dawned.

I read as much in your eye (beware, by-the-bye, what you express with that organ; I am quick at interpreting its language). Then take my word for it,--I am not a villain: you are not to suppose that--not to attribute to me any such bad eminence; but, owing, I verily believe, rather to circumstances than to my natural bent, I am a trite commonplace sinner, hackneyed in all the poor petty dissipations with which the rich and worthless try to put on life. Do you wonder that I avow this to you? Know, that in the course of your future life you will often find yourself elected the involuntary confidant of your acquaintances' secrets: people will instinctively find out, as I have done, that it is not your forte to tell of yourself, but to listen while others talk of themselves; they will feel, too, that you listen with no malevolent scorn of their indiscretion, but with a kind of innate sympathy; not the less comforting and encouraging because it is very unobtrusive in its manifestations."

In this situation, you (as Miss Eyre) should alert Mr. Rochester about the fire in his room. He is already aware that something is wrong, as he tells you that he must pay a visit to the second storey and that you should remain still and not call anyone. He does not want to involve Mrs. Fairfax or call for Leah, possibly because he does not want to cause unnecessary panic or because he wants to handle the situation himself. It is also possible that he does not want to reveal the fire to others at this point. As for why he asks you to remain still and not call anyone, it could be because he does not want to put you in danger or because he wants to assess the situation himself before involving others.

"Shall I call Mrs. Fairfax?" I asked.
"Mrs. Fairfax? No; what the deuce would you call her for? What can she do? Let her sleep unmolested."
"Then I will fetch Leah, and wake John and his wife."
"Not at all: just be still. You have a shawl on. If you are not warm enough, you may take my cloak yonder; wrap it about you, and sit down in the arm-chair: there,--I will put it on. Now place your feet on the stool, to keep them out of the wet. I am going to leave you a few minutes. I shall take the candle. Remain where you are till I return; be as still as a mouse. Though I had now extinguished my candle and was laid down in bed, I could not sleep for thinking of his look when he paused in the avenue, and told how his destiny had risen up before him, and dared him to be happy at Thornfield.
"Why not?" I asked myself. "What alienates him from the house? Will he leave it again soon? Mrs. Fairfax said he seldom stayed here longer than a fortnight at a time; and he has now been resident eight weeks. If he does go, the change will be doleful. Suppose he should be absent spring, summer, and autumn: how joyless sunshine and fine days will seem!"
I hardly know whether I had slept or not after this musing; at any rate, I started wide awake on hearing a vague murmur, peculiar and lugubrious, which sounded, I thought, just above me. I wished I had kept my candle burning: the night was d

Ere long, steps retreated up the gallery towards the third-storey staircase: a door had lately been made to shut in that staircase; I heard it open and close, and all was still.
"Was that Grace Poole? and is she possessed with a devil?" thought I. Impossible now to remain longer by myself: I must go to Mrs. Fairfax. I hurried on my frock and a shawl; I withdrew the bolt and opened the door with a trembling hand. There was a candle burning just outside, and on the matting in the gallery. I was surprised at this circumstance: but still more was I amazed to perceive the air quite dim, as if filled with smoke; and, while looking to the right hand and left, to find whence these blue wreaths issued, I became further aware of a strong smell of burning.
Something creaked: it was a door ajar; and that door was Mr. Rochester's, and the smoke rushed in a cloud from thence. I thought no more of Mrs. Fairfax; I thought no more of Grace Poole, or the laugh: in an

c'est beau!" and then remained absorbed in ecstatic contemplation.
"Is Miss Eyre there?" now demanded the master, half rising from his seat to look round to the door, near which I still stood.
"Ah! well, come forward; be seated here." He drew a chair near his own. "I am not fond of the prattle of children," he continued; "for, old bachelor as I am, I have no pleasant associations connected with their lisp. It would be intolerable to me to pass a whole evening _tete-a-tete_ with a brat. Don't draw that chair farther off, Miss Eyre; sit down exactly where I placed it--if you please, that is. Confound these civilities! I continually forget them. Nor do I particularly affect simple-minded old ladies. By-the-bye, I must have mine in mind; it won't do to neglect her; she is a Fairfax, or wed to one; and blood is said to be thicker than water."
He rang, and despatched an invitation to Mrs. Fairfax,

He seemed surprised--very inconsistently so, as he had just told me to go.
"What!" he exclaimed, "are you quitting me already, and in that way?"
"You said I might go, sir."
"But not without taking leave; not without a word or two of acknowledgment and good-will: not, in short, in that brief, dry fashion. Why, you have saved my life!--snatched me from a horrible and excruciating death! and you walk past me as if we were mutual strangers! At least shake hands."

Mr. Rochester refers to the power of making "unheard-of combinations of circumstances" demand "unheard-of rules." He is implying the power to determine what is right or wrong, even if it goes against conventional norms and requires new laws or rules. This power is usually attributed to a divine or perfect being, and Mr. Rochester acknowledges that it is liable to abuse by humans who are "human and fallible."
This relates to the "unheard-of combinations of circumstances" that Mr. Rochester mentioned earlier because he is suggesting that the unusual situation he finds himself in requires him to make a new rule or law to justify his actions. However, Miss Eyre rightly points out that this is a dangerous maxim because it can be easily abused. Mr. Rochester acknowledges this but swears by his "household gods" not to abuse it.
In summary, Mr. Rochester refers to the power to make new rules or laws based on one's judgment, which is usually attributed to a divine or perfect being. He acknowledges that this power is liable to abuse but swears not to abuse it. This power is related to the "unheard-of combinations of circumstances" that Mr. Rochester mentioned earlier because he is suggesting that the unusual situation he finds himself in requires him to make a new rule or law to justify his actions.

"And better?"
"And better--so much better as pure ore is than foul dross. You seem to doubt me; I don't doubt myself: I know what my aim is, what my motives are; and at this moment I pass a law, unalterable as that of the Medes and Persians, that both are right."
"They cannot be, sir, if they require a new statute to legalise them."
"They are, Miss Eyre, though they absolutely require a new statute: unheard-of combinations of circumstances demand unheard-of rules."
"That sounds a dangerous maxim, sir; because one can see at once that it is liable to abuse."
"Sententious sage! so it is: but I swear by my household gods not to abuse it."
"You are human and fallible."
"I am: so are you--what then?"
"The human and fallible should not arrogate a power with which the divine and perfect alone can be safely intrusted."
"What power?"
"That of saying of any strange, unsanctioned line of action,

it?"
"Sir, I was too plain; I beg your pardon. I ought to have replied that it was not easy to give an impromptu answer to a question about appearances; that tastes mostly differ; and that beauty is of little consequence, or something of that sort."
"You ought to have replied no such thing. Beauty of little consequence, indeed! And so, under pretence of softening the previous outrage, of stroking and soothing me into placidity, you stick a sly penknife under my ear! Go on: what fault do you find with me, pray? I suppose I have all my limbs and all my features like any other man?"
"Mr. Rochester, allow me to disown my first answer: I intended no pointed repartee: it was only a blunder."
"Just so: I think so: and you shall be answerable for it. Criticise me: does my forehead not please you?"

Rochester _is_ peculiar--he seems to forget that he pays me 30 pounds per annum for receiving his orders.
"The smile is very well," said he, catching instantly the passing expression; "but speak too."
"I was thinking, sir, that very few masters would trouble themselves to inquire whether or not their paid subordinates were piqued and hurt by their orders."
"Paid subordinates! What! you are my paid subordinate, are you? Oh yes, I had forgotten the salary! Well then, on that mercenary ground, will you agree to let me hector a little?"
"No, sir, not on that ground; but, on the ground that you did forget it, and that you care whether or not a dependent is comfortable in his dependency, I agree heartily."
"And will you consent to dispense with a great many conventional forms and phrases, without thinking that the omission arises from insolence?"
"I am sure, sir, I should never mistake informality for insolence: one I rather like, the other nothing free-born would submit to, even for a salary."

I steadily reviewed the tale Mr. Rochester had told me. As he had said, there was probably nothing at all extraordinary in the substance of the narrative itself: a wealthy Englishman's passion for a French dancer, and her treachery to him, were every-day matters enough, no doubt, in society; but there was something decidedly strange in the paroxysm of emotion which had suddenly seized him when he was in the act of expressing the present contentment of his mood, and his newly revived pleasure in the old hall and its environs. I meditated wonderingly on this incident; but gradually quitting it, as I found it for the present inexplicable, I turned to the consideration of my master's manner to myself. The confidence he had thought fit to repose in me seemed a tribute to my discretion: I regarded and accepted it as such. His deportment had now for some weeks been more uniform towards me than at the first. I never seemed in his way; he did not take fits of chilling hauteur: when he met me unexpectedly, the encounter seemed welcome; he had always a word

should never mistake informality for insolence: one I rather like, the other nothing free-born would submit to, even for a salary."
"Humbug! Most things free-born will submit to anything for a salary; therefore, keep to yourself, and don't venture on generalities of which you are intensely ignorant. However, I mentally shake hands with you for your answer, despite its inaccuracy; and as much for the manner in which it was said, as for the substance of the speech; the manner was frank and sincere; one does not often see such a manner: no, on the contrary, affectation, or coldness, or stupid, coarse-minded misapprehension of one's meaning are the usual rewards of candour. Not three in three thousand raw school-girl-governesses would have answered me as you have just done. But I don't mean to flatter you: if you are cast in a different mould to the majority, it is no merit of yours: Nature did it. In the narrative, Jane Eyre quickly takes action to save Mr. Rochester and his bed from burning by using water from the basin, ewer, and her own water-jug. Here's the step-by-step process of what she does:
1. Wakes up to the sight of flames around Mr. Rochester's bed, caused by the curtains being on fire. 2. Realizes that Mr. Rochester is in a deep sleep and the smoke has stupefied him, so she cannot rely on him to wake up and help. 3. Shouts "Wake! wake!" and shakes Mr. Rochester, but he only murmurs and turns, so she knows she needs to take matters into her own hands. 4. Rushes to Mr. Rochester's basin and ewer, which are both filled with water. She is fortunate that one is wide and the other is deep, allowing her to scoop up a significant amount of water. 5. Deluges the bed and its occupant (Mr. Rochester) with the water from the basin and ewer. 6. Quickly goes back to her own room and brings her own water-jug, using it to baptize the couch (the bed) again, ensuring that she extinguishes all the flames. 7. The hiss of the quenched element, the breakage of a pitcher she flung away after emptying it, and the splash of the shower-bath she had liberally bestowed rouse Mr. Rochester from his sleep.
Thanks to Jane Eyre's quick thinking and actions, she successfully saves Mr. Rochester and his bed from burning.

a cloud from thence. I thought no more of Mrs. Fairfax; I thought no more of Grace Poole, or the laugh: in an instant, I was within the chamber. Tongues of flame darted round the bed: the curtains were on fire. In the midst of blaze and vapour, Mr. Rochester lay stretched motionless, in deep sleep.
"Wake! wake!" I cried. I shook him, but he only murmured and turned: the smoke had stupefied him. Not a moment could be lost: the very sheets were kindling, I rushed to his basin and ewer; fortunately, one was wide and the other deep, and both were filled with water. I heaved them up, deluged the bed and its occupant, flew back to my own room, brought my own water-jug, baptized the couch afresh, and, by God's aid, succeeded in extinguishing the flames which were devouring it.
The hiss of the quenched element, the breakage of a pitcher which I flung from my hand when I had emptied it, and, above all

hiss of the quenched element, the breakage of a pitcher which I flung from my hand when I had emptied it, and, above all, the splash of the shower-bath I had liberally bestowed, roused Mr. Rochester at last. Though it was now dark, I knew he was awake; because I heard him fulminating strange anathemas at finding himself lying in a pool of water.
"Is there a flood?" he cried.
"No, sir," I answered; "but there has been a fire: get up, do; you are quenched now; I will fetch you a candle."
"In the name of all the elves in Christendom, is that Jane Eyre?" he demanded. "What have you done with me, witch, sorceress? Who is in the room besides you? Have you plotted to drown me?"
"I will fetch you a candle, sir; and, in Heaven's name, get up. Somebody has plotted something: you cannot too soon find out who and what it is."

I ought to be at liberty to attend to my own pleasure. Miss Eyre, draw your chair still a little farther forward: you are yet too far back; I cannot see you without disturbing my position in this comfortable chair, which I have no mind to do."
I did as I was bid, though I would much rather have remained somewhat in the shade; but Mr. Rochester had such a direct way of giving orders, it seemed a matter of course to obey him promptly.
We were, as I have said, in the dining-room: the lustre, which had been lit for dinner, filled the room with a festal breadth of light; the large fire was all red and clear; the purple curtains hung rich and ample before the lofty window and loftier arch; everything was still, save the subdued chat of Adele (she dared not speak loud), and, filling up each pause, the beating of winter rain against the panes.

The speaker, who is not named in the narrative, reveals that they have a past filled with "poor petty dissipations" and acknowledges that they have faults, which they attribute to circumstances rather than their natural tendencies. They mention that they started on a "wrong tack" at the age of twenty-one and have not recovered since. They describe themselves as a "trite commonplace sinner" and imply that they have a history that is not entirely virtuous. They also mention that the person they are speaking to will often find themselves in the role of confidant, as they have a knack for listening to others' secrets with sympathy. The speaker's past and their acknowledgment of their own faults suggest a complex character with a history of mistakes and regrets.

no merit of yours: Nature did it. And then, after all, I go too fast in my conclusions: for what I yet know, you may be no better than the rest; you may have intolerable defects to counterbalance your few good points."
"And so may you," I thought. My eye met his as the idea crossed my mind: he seemed to read the glance, answering as if its import had been spoken as well as imagined--
"Yes, yes, you are right," said he; "I have plenty of faults of my own: I know it, and I don't wish to palliate them, I assure you. God wot I need not be too severe about others; I have a past existence, a series of deeds, a colour of life to contemplate within my own breast, which might well call my sneers and censures from my neighbours to myself. I started, or rather (for like other defaulters, I like to lay half the blame on ill fortune and adverse circumstances) was thrust on to a wrong tack at the age of one-and-twenty, and have never recovered the right

tiens_, as Adele would say; and it is by virtue of this superiority, and this alone, that I desire you to have the goodness to talk to me a little now, and divert my thoughts, which are galled with dwelling on one point--cankering as a rusty nail."
He had deigned an explanation, almost an apology, and I did not feel insensible to his condescension, and would not seem so.

The peculiar and lugubrious sound heard above the narrator's head is never explicitly identified, but it is initially attributed to Pilot, Mr. Rochester's dog, who is known to wander into the hallway from the kitchen. The sound causes fear and anxiety in the narrator because it is hushed, irregular, and seems to be coming from the dark gallery outside her door. This mysterious sound, combined with the late hour and the darkness, leads to a feeling of unease and suspicion that it might be something or someone unfamiliar. The narrator's active imagination and the gloomy atmosphere of the old house also contribute to her fear and anxiety.

peculiar and lugubrious, which sounded, I thought, just above me. I wished I had kept my candle burning: the night was drearily dark; my spirits were depressed. I rose and sat up in bed, listening. The sound was hushed.
I tried again to sleep; but my heart beat anxiously: my inward tranquillity was broken. The clock, far down in the hall, struck two. Just then it seemed my chamber-door was touched; as if fingers had swept the panels in groping a way along the dark gallery outside. I said, "Who is there?" Nothing answered. I was chilled with fear.
All at once I remembered that it might be Pilot, who, when the kitchen- door chanced to be left open, not unfrequently found his way up to the threshold of Mr. Rochester's chamber: I had seen him lying there myself in the mornings. The idea calmed me somewhat: I lay down. Silence composes the nerves; and as an unbroken hush now reigned again through the whole house, I began to feel the return of slumber.

This was a demoniac laugh--low, suppressed, and deep--uttered, as it seemed, at the very keyhole of my chamber door. The head of my bed was near the door, and I thought at first the goblin-laugher stood at my bedside--or rather, crouched by my pillow: but I rose, looked round, and could see nothing; while, as I still gazed, the unnatural sound was reiterated: and I knew it came from behind the panels. My first impulse was to rise and fasten the bolt; my next, again to cry out, "Who is there?"

He went: I watched the light withdraw. He passed up the gallery very softly, unclosed the staircase door with as little noise as possible, shut it after him, and the last ray vanished. I was left in total darkness. I listened for some noise, but heard nothing. A very long time elapsed. I grew weary: it was cold, in spite of the cloak; and then I did not see the use of staying, as I was not to rouse the house. I was on the point of risking Mr. Rochester's displeasure by disobeying his orders, when the light once more gleamed dimly on the gallery wall, and I heard his unshod feet tread the matting. "I hope it is he," thought I, "and not something worse."
He re-entered, pale and very gloomy. "I have found it all out," said he, setting his candle down on the washstand; "it is as I thought."

I had not, it seems, the originality to chalk out a new road to shame and destruction, but trode the old track with stupid exactness not to deviate an inch from the beaten centre. I had--as I deserved to have--the fate of all other spoonies.

The speaker believes that they have experienced a positive transformation after receiving what they perceive to be a "disguised deity" or divine presence in the form of a tempting suggestion. They describe their heart as having been a "charnel" before, which is a term used to describe a place where bodies are buried or a chamber for the dead. This suggests that the speaker saw their heart as a place of death and decay.
However, after receiving the tempting suggestion, the speaker describes their heart as becoming a "shrine," which is a place where a deity is worshipped or honored. This suggests that the speaker now sees their heart as a place of reverence and devotion, having been transformed by the divine presence they perceive in the tempting suggestion.
The speaker describes the tempting suggestion as "very genial, very soothing," and believes it to be an "inspiration rather than a temptation." They see it as a positive force that has done them good and has the potential to continue to do so.
Overall, the speaker believes that they have experienced a transformation from a state of death and decay to a state of reverence and devotion as a result of receiving the tempting suggestion they perceive to be a divine presence.

The speaker's 'cherished preserver' in this narrative is Mr. Rochester, who is described as speaking in an enigmatical language that bewilders Jane Eyre. He talks to her about a tempting suggestion that he perceives as a divine presence and a positive force that has transformed his heart from a place of death and decay to a place of reverence and devotion.
During their late-night encounter, Mr. Rochester's behavior is somewhat cryptic and difficult to understand. He speaks in riddles and uses language that Jane finds confusing. He also accuses her of being afraid of him, which she denies. Despite his confusing behavior, Jane remains calm and composed, and she handles the situation with grace and dignity.
The speaker, who is Jane in this context, responds to Mr. Rochester's actions by remaining respectful and polite, even though she does not understand what he is talking about. She tries to make sense of his words, but ultimately decides to end the conversation, stating that it is useless to continue. She then excuses herself to put Adele to bed, showing that she is still focused on her duties as a governess.
Overall, Jane's emotional state during this encounter is one of bewilderment and uncertainty. She is unsure of what Mr. Rochester is trying to convey, and she feels a sense of insecurity and ignorance. However, she remains calm and composed, and she responds to his actions with respect and dignity.

The speaker advises resisting temptation and choosing the path of reformation, as giving in to temptation may lead to degeneration and further sin. The speaker warns of the potential misery and bitterness that can result from yielding to temptation, and describes remorse as the "poison of life." However, the speaker expresses doubt about the possibility of reformation in their own situation, given their current circumstances. They acknowledge their past mistakes and faults, and imply that they have a history that is not entirely virtuous. The speaker also warns against underestimating the consequences of giving in to temptation, cautioning that the person tempted may not fully understand the potential outcomes.
The speaker believes that they have experienced a positive transformation after receiving a tempting suggestion that they perceive to be a "disguised deity" or divine presence. They describe their heart as having been a "charnel" before, but becoming a "shrine" after receiving the tempting suggestion. The speaker sees the tempting suggestion as a positive force that has done them good and has the potential to continue to do so.
Regarding remorse, the speaker believes that it is not the cure for error, but reformation may be. They express regret for not having stood firm in the face of adversity and for degenerating when fate wronged them. The speaker wishes they had remained cool and not turned desperate, but acknowledges that they did not have the wisdom to do so at the time. They advise distrusting any temptation that may arise, but also question the ability to distinguish between a true angel and a fallen seraph of the abyss or a guide and a seducer.

When Mlle. Varens, Mr. Rochester's former lover, entered the balcony with a cavalier, Mr. Rochester's mood dramatically changed from calm to jealousy. He describes the feeling as a green snake of jealousy that glided within his waistcoat and ate its way to his heart's core. This metaphor suggests the intensity of the emotion and how it quickly consumed him.
However, his jealousy was short-lived. When he recognized the cavalier as a young, brainless, and vicious vicomte, his love for Mlle. Varens sank, and his jealousy disappeared. He described her as not worth contending for and deserving only scorn, less for herself than for making him her dupe.
So, in summary, Mr. Rochester's mood changed from calm to intense jealousy when Mlle. Varens entered with a cavalier, but then his mood shifted to scorn and relief when he recognized the cavalier and lost interest in Mlle. Varens.

In the narrative, the speaker, Jane Eyre, is asked by Mr. Rochester if she thinks he is handsome. Jane responds honestly and says "No, sir." This response is not meant as an insult, but rather as a reflection of her personal taste and her focus on his inner qualities. She goes on to describe him as having "great, dark eyes, and very fine eyes, too" and notes that there is "a certain change in their depths sometimes, which, if it was not softness, reminded you, at least, of that feeling." These descriptions suggest that while Jane may not find Mr. Rochester traditionally handsome, she sees beauty in his eyes and finds him intriguing. Later in the narrative, Jane also reflects on Mr. Rochester's kindness to her and her belief that he has "excellent materials" within him, despite his moodiness and past faults. All of these factors suggest that Jane's initial response is not meant as a dismissal of Mr. Rochester's appearance, but rather as a nuanced and thoughtful assessment of his character.

I believed he was naturally a man of better tendencies, higher principles, and purer tastes than such as circumstances had developed, education instilled, or destiny encouraged. In the narrative, Mr. Rochester is asking Jane Eyre if she thinks he is handsome and Jane responds honestly by saying "No, sir." This response is not meant as an insult, but rather as a reflection of her personal taste and her focus on his inner qualities. However, the question you have posed refers to a different part of the narrative, where Jane is reflecting on Mr. Rochester's behavior towards her and how he seems to forget that she receives a salary of 30 pounds per annum to follow his orders.
There could be several reasons why Mr. Rochester might be overlooking this fact. One possibility is that he is so used to being in a position of power and authority that he does not even consider the fact that Jane is being paid for her services. It is also possible that he is so caught up in his own thoughts and concerns that he forgets about the practical arrangements of their working relationship.
Another possibility is that Mr. Rochester sees Jane as more than just a subordinate, and he may value her opinions and companionship beyond what she is being paid to provide. This could be why he is willing to confide in her and share personal information with her, even though she is technically an employee.
Overall, it is difficult to say for certain why Mr. Rochester is overlooking the fact that Jane is being paid to follow his orders. The narrative does not provide enough information to make a definitive judgment on this point.

In the narrative, Mr. Rochester and his subordinate, Jane Eyre, come to an agreement regarding his forgetfulness of the salary and his desire to use informal language. Jane agrees to let Mr. Rochester "hector a little" and to dispense with conventional forms and phrases, as long as he does not see her as just a paid subordinate and values her opinions and comfort beyond her salary. Mr. Rochester agrees to this, and also asks Jane to be honest with him and not to mistake informality for insolence. Jane agrees to this as well, and the two continue their working relationship on these terms.

The character, Mr. Rochester, is expressing his resolution to change his ways and improve himself, with the goal of having better associates and pursuits in the future. While it is not possible to ensure this outcome completely, he believes that by making a concerted effort to correct his thoughts and actions, he will naturally attract better influences and opportunities into his life. This is based on the idea that our surroundings and relationships are often a reflection of our own character and choices. By striving to become a better person and making more positive choices, he hopes to create new and stainless stores of recollections and lead a more fulfilling life.

Mr. Rochester discovered a fire in his room on the second storey of the house. He had previously been aware of the fire, which is why he told Jane to stay still and not call anyone, as he wanted to handle the situation himself and not cause unnecessary panic. His suspicion that something was wrong on the second storey was confirmed by his discovery of the fire. This is why he returned to Jane's room pale and gloomy, stating that he had found it all out and that it was as he thought. The fire was likely the source of the "peculiar and lugubrious" sound that Jane heard, as it would have been making crackling and popping noises as it burned.

There are several factors influencing Mr. Rochester's varying interactions with the narrator, Jane Eyre, during the period when he is frequently absent from home and has visitors over for dinner.
First, Mr. Rochester is preoccupied with his own concerns and may not be giving much thought to the practical arrangements of his working relationship with Jane. He is used to being in a position of power and authority, and may not even consider the fact that Jane is being paid for her services.
Second, Mr. Rochester may see Jane as more than just a subordinate. He may value her opinions and companionship beyond what she is being paid to provide, which could be why he is willing to confide in her and share personal information with her.
Third, Mr. Rochester may be trying to present a certain image to his guests and may be more formal and distant with Jane in order to maintain that image.
Fourth, the narrative suggests that Jane is still young and inexperienced, and has not yet experienced feelings of love and jealousy. It is possible that Mr. Rochester is aware of this and is trying to protect her from the complexities of his social circle.
Overall, Mr. Rochester's varying interactions with Jane during this period are likely influenced by a combination of these factors, as well as his own personal thoughts and feelings.

The 'marrow-freezing' incident that occurred on the night in question was hearing a demoniac laugh behind the keyhole of Jane's chamber door. She tried to sleep again but couldn't due to her fear and the silence that composed her nerves. The sound of the clock striking two and the sensation of her chamber-door being touched only added to her fear, making it impossible for her to sleep.

She feels a "strange energy" in his voice and a "strange fire" in his look, indicating a powerful and intense emotional connection to him. Despite being cold, she initially stays because she is glad to have been awake to experience his presence. Once she is back in her room, Jane is unable to sleep and is instead "tossed on a buoyant but unquiet sea, where billows of trouble rolled under surges of joy." Overall, Jane's emotional state is one of turmoil and uncertainty, as she tries to make sense of the intense emotions she is experiencing.

For several subsequent days I saw little of Mr. Rochester. In the mornings he seemed much engaged with business, and, in the afternoon, gentlemen from Millcote or the neighbourhood called, and sometimes stayed to dine with him. When his sprain was well enough to admit of horse exercise, he rode out a good deal; probably to return these visits, as he generally did not come back till late at night.
During this interval, even Adele was seldom sent for to his presence, and all my acquaintance with him was confined to an occasional rencontre in the hall, on the stairs, or in the gallery, when he would sometimes pass me haughtily and coldly, just acknowledging my presence by a distant nod or a cool glance, and sometimes bow and smile with gentlemanlike affability. His changes of mood did not offend me, because I saw that I had nothing to do with their alternation; the ebb and flow depended on causes quite disconnected with me.

The speaker is experiencing a transformation from a state of negativity and despair to a state of positivity and reverence after receiving what they perceive to be a "disguised deity" or divine presence in the form of a tempting suggestion. They describe their heart as a "charnel" before, which is a term used to describe a place where bodies are buried or a chamber for the dead. This suggests that the speaker saw their heart as a place of death and decay. However, after receiving the tempting suggestion, the speaker describes their heart as becoming a "shrine," which is a place where a deity is worshipped or honored. This suggests that the speaker now sees their heart as a place of reverence and devotion, having been transformed by the divine presence they perceive in the tempting suggestion. The speaker believes that the tempting suggestion is a positive force that has done them good and has the potential to continue to do so. They describe it as "very genial, very soothing," and believe it to be an "inspiration rather than a temptation."

When Mlle. Varens, Mr. Rochester's former lover, entered the balcony with a cavalier, Mr. Rochester's mood changed dramatically from calm to intense jealousy. He describes the feeling as a green snake of jealousy that glided within his waistcoat and ate its way to his heart's core. This metaphor suggests the intensity of the emotion and how quickly it consumed him. However, his jealousy was short-lived. When he recognized the cavalier as a young, brainless, and vicious vicomte, his love for Mlle. Varens sank, and his jealousy disappeared. He described her as not worth contending for and deserving only scorn, less for herself than for making him her dupe. In summary, Mr. Rochester's mood changed from calm to intense jealousy when Mlle. Varens entered with a cavalier, but then his mood shifted to scorn and relief when he recognized the cavalier and lost interest in Mlle. Varens.

The speaker advises resisting temptation and choosing the path of reformation, as giving in to temptation may lead to degeneration and further sin. They warn of the potential misery and bitterness that can result from yielding to temptation, and describe remorse as the "poison of life." However, the speaker expresses doubt about the possibility of reformation in their own situation, given their current circumstances. They also caution that the person tempted may not fully understand the potential outcomes of giving in to temptation.
Regarding repentance, the speaker believes that it is not the cure for error, but reformation may be. They express regret for not having stood firm in the face of adversity and for degenerating when fate wronged them. The speaker wishes they had remained cool and not turned desperate, but acknowledges that they did not have the wisdom to do so at the time. They advise distrusting any temptation that may arise, but also question the ability to distinguish between a true angel and a fallen seraph of the abyss or a guide and a seducer.

It is not possible to ensure with absolute certainty that one's resolution to correct thoughts and actions will result in becoming what one approves of and improving associates and pursuits. However, the general idea is that by making a concerted effort to improve oneself, one is likely to attract better influences and opportunities into their life. This is based on the principle that our surroundings and relationships are often a reflection of our own character and choices. By striving to become a better person and making more positive choices, it is more likely that better associates and pursuits will follow. However, this is not a guarantee, and there is always the possibility of setbacks or unforeseen circumstances. Nonetheless, the important thing is to make a sincere effort and remain committed to self-improvement.

"How do you know?--how can you guess all this, sir?"
"I know it well; therefore I proceed almost as freely as if I were writing my thoughts in a diary. You would say, I should have been superior to circumstances; so I should--so I should; but you see I was not. When fate wronged me, I had not the wisdom to remain cool: I turned desperate; then I degenerated. Now, when any vicious simpleton excites my disgust by his paltry ribaldry, I cannot flatter myself that I am better than he: I am forced to confess that he and I are on a level. I wish I had stood firm--God knows I do! Dread remorse when you are tempted to err, Miss Eyre; remorse is the poison of life."

There was a smile on his lips, and his eyes sparkled, whether with wine or not, I am not sure; but I think it very probable. He was, in short, in his after-dinner mood; more expanded and genial, and also more self- indulgent than the frigid and rigid temper of the morning; still he looked preciously grim, cushioning his massive head against the swelling back of his chair, and receiving the light of the fire on his granite- hewn features, and in his great, dark eyes; for he had great, dark eyes, and very fine eyes, too--not without a certain change in their depths sometimes, which, if it was not softness, reminded you, at least, of that feeling.

Mr. Rochester refers to the power of making "unheard-of combinations of circumstances" demand "unheard-of rules." He is implying the power to determine what is right or wrong, even if it goes against conventional norms and requires new laws or rules. This power is usually attributed to a divine or perfect being, and Mr. Rochester acknowledges that it is liable to abuse by humans who are "human and fallible."
This relates to the "unheard-of combinations of circumstances" that Mr. Rochester mentioned earlier because he is suggesting that the unusual situation he finds himself in requires him to make a new rule or law to justify his actions. However, Miss Eyre rightly points out that this is a dangerous maxim because it can be easily abused. Mr. Rochester acknowledges this but swears by his "household gods" not to abuse it.
In summary, Mr. Rochester refers to the power to make new rules or laws based on one's judgment, which is usually attributed to a divine or perfect being. He acknowledges that this power is liable to abuse but swears not to abuse it. This power is related to the "unheard-of combinations of circumstances" that Mr. Rochester mentioned earlier because he is suggesting that the unusual situation he finds himself in requires him to make a new rule or law to justify his actions.

In the narrative, Jane Eyre quickly takes action to save Mr. Rochester and his bed from burning by using water from the basin, ewer, and her own water-jug. Here's the step-by-step process of what she does:
1. Wakes up to the sight of flames around Mr. Rochester's bed, caused by the curtains being on fire. 2. Realizes that Mr. Rochester is in a deep sleep and the smoke has stupefied him, so she cannot rely on him to wake up and help. 3. Shouts "Wake! wake!" and shakes Mr. Rochester, but he only murmurs and turns, so she knows she needs to take matters into her own hands. 4. Rushes to Mr. Rochester's basin and ewer, which are both filled with water. She is fortunate that one is wide and the other is deep, allowing her to scoop up a significant amount of water. 5. Deluges the bed and its occupant (Mr. Rochester) with the water from the basin and ewer. 6. Quickly goes back to her own room and brings her own water-jug, using it to baptize the couch (the bed) again, ensuring that she extinguishes all the flames. 7. The hiss of the quenched element, the breakage of a pitcher she flung away after emptying it, and the splash of the shower-bath she had liberally bestowed rouse Mr. Rochester from his sleep.
Thanks to Jane Eyre's quick thinking and actions, she successfully saves Mr. Rochester and his bed from burning.

The speaker's 'cherished preserver' in this narrative is Mr. Rochester, who is described as speaking in an enigmatical language that bewilders Jane Eyre. He talks to her about a tempting suggestion that he perceives as a divine presence and a positive force that has transformed his heart from a place of death and decay to a place of reverence and devotion.
During their late-night encounter, Mr. Rochester's behavior is somewhat cryptic and difficult to understand. He speaks in riddles and uses language that Jane finds confusing. He also accuses her of being afraid of him, which she denies. Despite his confusing behavior, Jane remains calm and composed, and she handles the situation with grace and dignity.
The speaker, who is Jane in this context, responds to Mr. Rochester's actions by remaining respectful and polite, even though she does not understand what he is talking about. She tries to make sense of his words, but ultimately decides to end the conversation, stating that it is useless to continue. She then excuses herself to put Adele to bed, showing that she is still focused on her duties as a governess.
Overall, Jane's emotional state during this encounter is one of bewilderment and uncertainty. She is unsure of what Mr. Rochester is trying to convey, and she feels a sense of insecurity and ignorance. However, she remains calm and composed, and she responds to his actions with respect and dignity.

There are several factors influencing Mr. Rochester's varying interactions with the narrator, Jane Eyre, during the period when he is frequently absent from home and has visitors over for dinner.
First, Mr. Rochester is preoccupied with his own concerns and may not be giving much thought to the practical arrangements of his working relationship with Jane. He is used to being in a position of power and authority, and may not even consider the fact that Jane is being paid for her services.
Second, Mr. Rochester may see Jane as more than just a subordinate. He may value her opinions and companionship beyond what she is being paid to provide, which could be why he is willing to confide in her and share personal information with her.
Third, Mr. Rochester may be trying to present a certain image to his guests and may be more formal and distant with Jane in order to maintain that image.
Fourth, the narrative suggests that Jane is still young and inexperienced, and has not yet experienced feelings of love and jealousy. It is possible that Mr. Rochester is aware of this and is trying to protect her from the complexities of his social circle.
Overall, Mr. Rochester's varying interactions with Jane during this period are likely influenced by a combination of these factors, as well as his own personal thoughts and feelings.

edge.source:
damask-covered chair, looked different to what I had seen him look before; not quite so stern--much less gloomy. There was a smile on his lips, and his eyes sparkled, whether with wine or not, I am not sure; but I think it very probable. He was, in short, in his after-dinner mood; more expanded and genial, and also more self- indulgent than the frigid and rigid temper of the morning; still he looked preciously grim, cushioning his massive head against the swelling back of his chair, and receiving the light of the fire on his granite- hewn features, and in his great, dark eyes; for he had great, dark eyes, and very fine eyes, too--not without a certain change in their depths sometimes, which, if it was not softness, reminded you, at least, of that feeling.
He had been looking two minutes at the fire, and I had been looking the same length of time at him, when, turning suddenly, he caught my gaze fastened on his physiognomy.
"You examine me, Miss Eyre," said he:
edge.target: In the narrative, the speaker, Jane Eyre, is asked by Mr. Rochester if she thinks he is handsome. Jane responds honestly and says "No, sir." This response is not meant as an insult, but rather as a reflection of her personal taste and her focus on his inner qualities. She goes on to describe him as having "great, dark eyes, and very fine eyes, too" and notes that there is "a certain change in their depths sometimes, which, if it was not softness, reminded you, at least, of that feeling." These descriptions suggest that while Jane may not find Mr. Rochester traditionally handsome, she sees beauty in his eyes and finds him intriguing. Later in the narrative, Jane also reflects on Mr. Rochester's kindness to her and her belief that he has "excellent materials" within him, despite his moodiness and past faults. All of these factors suggest that Jane's initial response is not meant as a dismissal of Mr. Rochester's appearance, but rather as a nuanced and thoughtful assessment of his character.

edge.source:
old as you, I was a feeling fellow enough, partial to the unfledged, unfostered, and unlucky; but Fortune has knocked me about since: she has even kneaded me with her knuckles, and now I flatter myself I am hard and tough as an India-rubber ball; pervious, though, through a chink or two still, and with one sentient point in the middle of the lump. Yes: does that leave hope for me?"
"Hope of what, sir?"
"Of my final re-transformation from India-rubber back to flesh?"
"Decidedly he has had too much wine," I thought; and I did not know what answer to make to his queer question: how could I tell whether he was capable of being re-transformed?

edge.target:
you neophyte, that have not passed the porch of life, and are absolutely unacquainted with its mysteries."
"I only remind you of your own words, sir: you said error brought remorse, and you pronounced remorse the poison of existence."
"And who talks of error now? I scarcely think the notion that flittered across my brain was an error. I believe it was an inspiration rather than a temptation: it was very genial, very soothing--I know that. Here it comes again! It is no devil, I assure you; or if it be, it has put on the robes of an angel of light. I think I must admit so fair a guest when it asks entrance to my heart."
"Distrust it, sir; it is not a true angel."
"Once more, how do you know? By what instinct do you pretend to distinguish between a fallen seraph of the abyss and a messenger from the eternal throne--between a guide and a seducer?"
"I judged by your countenance, sir, which was troubled when you said the suggestion had returned upon you.

edge.target:
"It is not its cure. Reformation may be its cure; and I could reform--I have strength yet for that--if--but where is the use of thinking of it, hampered, burdened, cursed as I am? Besides, since happiness is irrevocably denied me, I have a right to get pleasure out of life: and I _will_ get it, cost what it may."
"Then you will degenerate still more, sir."
"Possibly: yet why should I, if I can get sweet, fresh pleasure? And I may get it as sweet and fresh as the wild honey the bee gathers on the moor."
"It will sting--it will taste bitter, sir."
"How do you know?--you never tried it. How very serious--how very solemn you look: and you are as ignorant of the matter as this cameo head" (taking one from the mantelpiece). "You have no right to preach to me, you neophyte, that have not passed the porch of life, and are absolutely unacquainted with its mysteries."

edge.target: dawned I was tossed on a buoyant but unquiet sea, where billows of trouble rolled under surges of joy. I thought sometimes I saw beyond its wild waters a shore, sweet as the hills of Beulah; and now and then a freshening gale, wakened by hope, bore my spirit triumphantly towards the bourne: but I could not reach it, even in fancy--a counteracting breeze blew off land, and continually drove me back. Sense would resist delirium: judgment would warn passion. Too feverish to rest, I rose as soon as day dawned.

edge.target:
I read as much in your eye (beware, by-the-bye, what you express with that organ; I am quick at interpreting its language). Then take my word for it,--I am not a villain: you are not to suppose that--not to attribute to me any such bad eminence; but, owing, I verily believe, rather to circumstances than to my natural bent, I am a trite commonplace sinner, hackneyed in all the poor petty dissipations with which the rich and worthless try to put on life. Do you wonder that I avow this to you? Know, that in the course of your future life you will often find yourself elected the involuntary confidant of your acquaintances' secrets: people will instinctively find out, as I have done, that it is not your forte to tell of yourself, but to listen while others talk of themselves; they will feel, too, that you listen with no malevolent scorn of their indiscretion, but with a kind of innate sympathy; not the less comforting and encouraging because it is very unobtrusive in its manifestations."

The speaker's 'cherished preserver' in this narrative is Mr. Rochester, who is described as speaking in an enigmatical language that bewilders Jane Eyre. During their late-night encounter, Mr. Rochester's behavior is somewhat cryptic and difficult to understand. He speaks in riddles and uses language that Jane finds confusing. He also accuses her of being afraid of him, which she denies. Despite his confusing behavior, Jane remains calm and composed, and she handles the situation with grace and dignity.
The speaker, who is Jane in this context, responds to Mr. Rochester's actions by remaining respectful and polite, even though she does not understand what he is talking about. She tries to make sense of his words, but ultimately decides to end the conversation, stating that it is useless to continue. She then excuses herself to put Adele to bed, showing that she is still focused on her duties as a governess.
Overall, Jane's emotional state during this encounter is one of bewilderment and uncertainty. She is unsure of what Mr. Rochester is trying to convey, and she feels a sense of insecurity and ignorance. However, she remains calm and composed, and she responds to his actions with respect and dignity.

you neophyte, that have not passed the porch of life, and are absolutely unacquainted with its mysteries."
"I only remind you of your own words, sir: you said error brought remorse, and you pronounced remorse the poison of existence."
"And who talks of error now? I scarcely think the notion that flittered across my brain was an error. I believe it was an inspiration rather than a temptation: it was very genial, very soothing--I know that. Here it comes again! It is no devil, I assure you; or if it be, it has put on the robes of an angel of light. I think I must admit so fair a guest when it asks entrance to my heart."
"Distrust it, sir; it is not a true angel."
"Once more, how do you know? By what instinct do you pretend to distinguish between a fallen seraph of the abyss and a messenger from the eternal throne--between a guide and a seducer?"
"I judged by your countenance, sir, which was troubled when you said the suggestion had returned upon you.

edge.target: The 'marrow-freezing' incident that occurred on the night in question was hearing a demoniac laugh behind the keyhole of Jane's chamber door. This incident caused her to be unable to sleep because it was a scary and unsettling experience that made her heart beat anxiously and broke her inward tranquility. She tried to sleep again but couldn't due to her fear and the silence that composed her nerves. The sound of the clock striking two and the sensation of her chamber-door being touched only added to her fear, making it impossible for her to sleep.

edge.source:
"It is not its cure. Reformation may be its cure; and I could reform--I have strength yet for that--if--but where is the use of thinking of it, hampered, burdened, cursed as I am? Besides, since happiness is irrevocably denied me, I have a right to get pleasure out of life: and I _will_ get it, cost what it may."
"Then you will degenerate still more, sir."
"Possibly: yet why should I, if I can get sweet, fresh pleasure? And I may get it as sweet and fresh as the wild honey the bee gathers on the moor."
"It will sting--it will taste bitter, sir."
"How do you know?--you never tried it. How very serious--how very solemn you look: and you are as ignorant of the matter as this cameo head" (taking one from the mantelpiece). "You have no right to preach to me, you neophyte, that have not passed the porch of life, and are absolutely unacquainted with its mysteries."
"I only remind you

and a seducer?"
"I judged by your countenance, sir, which was troubled when you said the suggestion had returned upon you. I feel sure it will work you more misery if you listen to it."
"Not at all--it bears the most gracious message in the world: for the rest, you are not my conscience-keeper, so don't make yourself uneasy. Here, come in, bonny wanderer!"
He said this as if he spoke to a vision, viewless to any eye but his own; then, folding his arms, which he had half extended, on his chest, he seemed to enclose in their embrace the invisible being.
"Now," he continued, again addressing me, "I have received the pilgrim--a disguised deity, as I verily believe. Already it has done me good: my heart was a sort of charnel; it will now be a shrine."
"To speak truth, sir, I don't understand you at all: I cannot keep up the conversation, because it has got out of my depth. Only one thing, I know: you said

edge.source:
I read as much in your eye (beware, by-the-bye, what you express with that organ; I am quick at interpreting its language). Then take my word for it,--I am not a villain: you are not to suppose that--not to attribute to me any such bad eminence; but, owing, I verily believe, rather to circumstances than to my natural bent, I am a trite commonplace sinner, hackneyed in all the poor petty dissipations with which the rich and worthless try to put on life. Do you wonder that I avow this to you? Know, that in the course of your future life you will often find yourself elected the involuntary confidant of your acquaintances' secrets: people will instinctively find out, as I have done, that it is not your forte to tell of yourself, but to listen while others talk of themselves; they will feel, too, that you listen with no malevolent scorn of their indiscretion, but with a kind of innate sympathy; not the less comforting and encouraging because it is very unobtrusive in its manifestations."
"How do you know?--how can you guess all

He listened very gravely; his face, as I went on, expressed more concern than astonishment; he did not immediately speak when I had concluded.
"Shall I call Mrs. Fairfax?" I asked.
"Mrs. Fairfax? No; what the deuce would you call her for? What can she do? Let her sleep unmolested."
"Then I will fetch Leah, and wake John and his wife."
"Not at all: just be still. You have a shawl on. If you are not warm enough, you may take my cloak yonder; wrap it about you, and sit down in the arm-chair: there,--I will put it on. Now place your feet on the stool, to keep them out of the wet. I am going to leave you a few minutes. I shall take the candle. Remain where you are till I return; be as still as a mouse. I must pay a visit to the second storey. Don't move, remember, or call any one

edge.target:
they hung together somewhat spoiled and tangled. I cannot deny that I grieved for his grief, whatever that was, and would have given much to assuage it.
Though I had now extinguished my candle and was laid down in bed, I could not sleep for thinking of his look when he paused in the avenue, and told how his destiny had risen up before him, and dared him to be happy at Thornfield.
"Why not?" I asked myself. "What alienates him from the house? Will he leave it again soon? Mrs. Fairfax said he seldom stayed here longer than a fortnight at a time; and he has now been resident eight weeks. If he does go, the change will be doleful. Suppose he should be absent spring, summer, and autumn: how joyless sunshine and fine days will seem!"
I hardly know whether I had slept or not after this musing; at any rate, I started wide awake on hearing a vague murmur, peculiar and lugubrious, which sounded, I thought, just above me. I wished I had kept my candle burning: the night was d

Ere long, steps retreated up the gallery towards the third-storey staircase: a door had lately been made to shut in that staircase; I heard it open and close, and all was still.
"Was that Grace Poole? and is she possessed with a devil?" thought I. Impossible now to remain longer by myself: I must go to Mrs. Fairfax. I hurried on my frock and a shawl; I withdrew the bolt and opened the door with a trembling hand. There was a candle burning just outside, and on the matting in the gallery. I was surprised at this circumstance: but still more was I amazed to perceive the air quite dim, as if filled with smoke; and, while looking to the right hand and left, to find whence these blue wreaths issued, I became further aware of a strong smell of burning.
Something creaked: it was a door ajar; and that door was Mr. Rochester's, and the smoke rushed in a cloud from thence. I thought no more of Mrs. Fairfax; I thought no more of Grace Poole, or the laugh: in an

"Is Miss Eyre there?" now demanded the master, half rising from his seat to look round to the door, near which I still stood.
"Ah! well, come forward; be seated here." He drew a chair near his own. "I am not fond of the prattle of children," he continued; "for, old bachelor as I am, I have no pleasant associations connected with their lisp. It would be intolerable to me to pass a whole evening _tete-a-tete_ with a brat. Don't draw that chair farther off, Miss Eyre; sit down exactly where I placed it--if you please, that is. Confound these civilities! I continually forget them. Nor do I particularly affect simple-minded old ladies. By-the-bye, I must have mine in mind; it won't do to neglect her; she is a Fairfax, or wed to one; and blood is said to be thicker than water."

edge.target:
In the narrative, Jane Eyre quickly takes action to save Mr. Rochester and his bed from burning by using water from the basin, ewer, and her own water-jug. Here's the step-by-step process of what she does:
1. Wakes up to the sight of flames around Mr. Rochester's bed, caused by the curtains being on fire. 2. Realizes that Mr. Rochester is in a deep sleep and the smoke has stupefied him, so she cannot rely on him to wake up and help. 3. Shouts "Wake! wake!" and shakes Mr. Rochester, but he only murmurs and turns, so she knows she needs to take matters into her own hands. 4. Rushes to Mr. Rochester's basin and ewer, which are both filled with water. She is fortunate that one is wide and the other is deep, allowing her to scoop up a significant amount of water. 5. Deluges the bed and its occupant (Mr. Rochester) with the water from the basin and ewer. 6. Quickly goes back to her own room and brings her own water-jug, using it to baptize the couch (the bed) again, ensuring that she extinguishes all the flames. 7. The hiss of the quenched element, the breakage of a pitcher she flung away after emptying it, and the splash of the shower-bath she had liberally bestowed rouse Mr. Rochester from his sleep.
Thanks to Jane Eyre's quick thinking and actions, she successfully saves Mr. Rochester and his bed from burning.

edge.target: Mr. Rochester discovered a fire in his room on the second storey of the house. He had previously been aware of the fire, which is why he told Jane to stay still and not call anyone, as he wanted to handle the situation himself and not cause unnecessary panic. His suspicion that something was wrong on the second storey was confirmed by his discovery of the fire. This is why he returned to Jane's room pale and gloomy, stating that he had found it all out and that it was as he thought. The fire was likely the source of the "peculiar and lugubrious" sound that Jane heard, as it would have been making crackling and popping noises as it burned.

edge.target: Grace Poole is a woman who works at Mr. Rochester's house, described as someone who sews and has a singular, peculiar laugh. The speaker suspects Grace Poole of being connected to the strange occurrence that happened on the night in question, which involved a demoniac laugh behind Jane's chamber door. The speaker is glad that only they and the listener are aware of the precise details of the incident, implying that Grace Poole's involvement is not common knowledge.

edge.target: Mr. Rochester expresses gratitude towards Jane because she has "saved his life" by preventing him from going to the top of the tower in a state of excitement, which could have resulted in a fatal accident. He is surprised that she is leaving without shaking his hand because, despite asking her to leave, he also wants a gesture of goodwill and acknowledgment for her actions. He feels a strong connection to Jane and wants to maintain a connection before she departs.

Mr. Rochester refers to the power of making "unheard-of combinations of circumstances" demand "unheard-of rules." He is implying the power to determine what is right or wrong, even if it goes against conventional norms and requires new laws or rules. This power is usually attributed to a divine or perfect being, and Mr. Rochester acknowledges that it is liable to abuse by humans who are "human and fallible."
This relates to the "unheard-of combinations of circumstances" that Mr. Rochester mentioned earlier because he is suggesting that the unusual situation he finds himself in requires him to make a new rule or law to justify his actions. However, Miss Eyre rightly points out that this is a dangerous maxim because it can be easily abused. Mr. Rochester acknowledges this but swears by his "household gods" not to abuse it.
In summary, Mr. Rochester refers to the power to make new rules or laws based on one's judgment, which is usually attributed to a divine or perfect being. He acknowledges that this power is liable to abuse but swears not to abuse it. This power is related to the "unheard-of combinations of circumstances" that Mr. Rochester mentioned earlier because he is suggesting that the unusual situation he finds himself in requires him to make a new rule or law to justify his actions.
edge.target:
"And better?"
"And better--so much better as pure ore is than foul dross. You seem to doubt me; I don't doubt myself: I know what my aim is, what my motives are; and at this moment I pass a law, unalterable as that of the Medes and Persians, that both are right."
"They cannot be, sir, if they require a new statute to legalise them."
"They are, Miss Eyre, though they absolutely require a new statute: unheard-of combinations of circumstances demand unheard-of rules."
"That sounds a dangerous maxim, sir; because one can see at once that it is liable to abuse."
"Sententious sage! so it is: but I swear by my household gods not to abuse it."
"You are human and fallible."
"I am: so are you--what then?"
"The human and fallible should not arrogate a power with which the divine and perfect alone can be safely intrusted."
"What power?"
"That of saying of any strange, unsanctioned line of action,

"You ought to have replied no such thing. Beauty of little consequence, indeed! "Mr. Rochester, allow me to disown my first answer: I intended no pointed repartee: it was only a blunder."

Rochester _is_ peculiar--he seems to forget that he pays me 30 pounds per annum for receiving his orders.
"The smile is very well," said he, catching instantly the passing expression; "but speak too."
"I was thinking, sir, that very few masters would trouble themselves to inquire whether or not their paid subordinates were piqued and hurt by their orders."
"Paid subordinates! What! you are my paid subordinate, are you? Oh yes, I had forgotten the salary! Well then, on that mercenary ground, will you agree to let me hector a little?"
"No, sir, not on that ground; but, on the ground that you did forget it, and that you care whether or not a dependent is comfortable in his dependency, I agree heartily."
"And will you consent to dispense with a great many conventional forms and phrases, without thinking that the omission arises from insolence?"
"I am sure, sir, I should never mistake informality for insolence: one I rather like, the other nothing free-born would submit to, even for a salary."

edge.target: I steadily reviewed the tale Mr. Rochester had told me. As he had said, there was probably nothing at all extraordinary in the substance of the narrative itself: a wealthy Englishman's passion for a French dancer, and her treachery to him, were every-day matters enough, no doubt, in society; but there was something decidedly strange in the paroxysm of emotion which had suddenly seized him when he was in the act of expressing the present contentment of his mood, and his newly revived pleasure in the old hall and its environs. I meditated wonderingly on this incident; but gradually quitting it, as I found it for the present inexplicable, I turned to the consideration of my master's manner to myself. The confidence he had thought fit to repose in me seemed a tribute to my discretion: I regarded and accepted it as such. His deportment had now for some weeks been more uniform towards me than at the first. I never seemed in his way; he did not take fits of chilling hauteur: when he met me unexpectedly, the encounter seemed welcome; he had always a word

should never mistake informality for insolence: one I rather like, the other nothing free-born would submit to, even for a salary."
"Humbug! Most things free-born will submit to anything for a salary; therefore, keep to yourself, and don't venture on generalities of which you are intensely ignorant. However, I mentally shake hands with you for your answer, despite its inaccuracy; and as much for the manner in which it was said, as for the substance of the speech; the manner was frank and sincere; one does not often see such a manner: no, on the contrary, affectation, or coldness, or stupid, coarse-minded misapprehension of one's meaning are the usual rewards of candour. Not three in three thousand raw school-girl-governesses would have answered me as you have just done. But I don't mean to flatter you: if you are cast in a different mould to the majority, it is no merit of yours: Nature did it. And then, after all, I go too fast in my conclusions: for what I yet know, you

edge.target: The speaker is experiencing a transformation from a state of negativity and despair to a state of positivity and reverence after receiving what they perceive to be a "disguised deity" or divine presence in the form of a tempting suggestion. They describe their heart as a "charnel" before, which is a term used to describe a place where bodies are buried or a chamber for the dead. This suggests that the speaker saw their heart as a place of death and decay. However, after receiving the tempting suggestion, the speaker describes their heart as becoming a "shrine," which is a place where a deity is worshipped or honored. This suggests that the speaker now sees their heart as a place of reverence and devotion, having been transformed by the divine presence they perceive in the tempting suggestion. The speaker believes that the tempting suggestion is a positive force that has done them good and has the potential to continue to do so. They describe it as "very genial, very soothing," and believe it to be an "inspiration rather than a temptation."

"Sir, I was too plain; I beg your pardon. I ought to have replied that it was not easy to give an impromptu answer to a question about appearances; that tastes mostly differ; and that beauty is of little consequence, or something of that sort."
"You ought to have replied no such thing. Beauty of little consequence, indeed! And so, under pretence of softening the previous outrage, of stroking and soothing me into placidity, you stick a sly penknife under my ear! Go on: what fault do you find with me, pray? I suppose I have all my limbs and all my features like any other man?"
"Mr. Rochester, allow me to disown my first answer: I intended no pointed repartee: it was only a blunder."
"Just so: I think so: and you shall be answerable for it. Criticise me: does my forehead not please you?"
He lifted up the sable waves of hair which lay horizontally over his brow, and showed a solid enough mass of intellectual organs, but an abrupt deficiency where the
edge.target: In the narrative, the speaker, Jane Eyre, is asked by Mr. Rochester if she thinks he is handsome. Jane responds honestly and says "No, sir." This response is not meant as an insult, but rather as a reflection of her personal taste and her focus on his inner qualities. She goes on to describe him as having "great, dark eyes, and very fine eyes, too" and notes that there is "a certain change in their depths sometimes, which, if it was not softness, reminded you, at least, of that feeling." These descriptions suggest that while Jane may not find Mr. Rochester traditionally handsome, she sees beauty in his eyes and finds him intriguing. Later in the narrative, Jane also reflects on Mr. Rochester's kindness to her and her belief that he has "excellent materials" within him, despite his moodiness and past faults. All of these factors suggest that Jane's initial response is not meant as a dismissal of Mr. Rochester's appearance, but rather as a nuanced and thoughtful assessment of his character.
