In the narrative, Mr. Rochester is asking Jane Eyre if she thinks he is handsome and Jane responds honestly by saying "No, sir." This response is not meant as an insult, but rather as a reflection of her personal taste and her focus on his inner qualities. However, the question you have posed refers to a different part of the narrative, where Jane is reflecting on Mr. Rochester's behavior towards her and how he seems to forget that she receives a salary of 30 pounds per annum to follow his orders.
There could be several reasons why Mr. Rochester might be overlooking this fact. One possibility is that he is so used to being in a position of power and authority that he does not even consider the fact that Jane is being paid for her services. It is also possible that he is so caught up in his own thoughts and concerns that he forgets about the practical arrangements of their working relationship.
Another possibility is that Mr. Rochester sees Jane as more than just a subordinate, and he may value her opinions and companionship beyond what she is being paid to provide. Overall, it is difficult to say for certain why Mr. Rochester is overlooking the fact that Jane is being paid to follow his orders. The narrative does not provide enough information to make a definitive judgment on this point.

edge.target: In the narrative, Mr. Rochester and his subordinate, Jane Eyre, come to an agreement regarding his forgetfulness of the salary and his desire to use informal language. Jane agrees to let Mr. Rochester "hector a little" and to dispense with conventional forms and phrases, as long as he does not see her as just a paid subordinate and values her opinions and comfort beyond her salary. Mr. Rochester agrees to this, and also asks Jane to be honest with him and not to mistake informality for insolence. Jane agrees to this as well, and the two continue their working relationship on these terms.

edge.target: Mr. Rochester discovered a fire in his room on the second storey of the house. He had previously been aware of the fire, which is why he told Jane to stay still and not call anyone, as he wanted to handle the situation himself and not cause unnecessary panic. His suspicion that something was wrong on the second storey was confirmed by his discovery of the fire. This is why he returned to Jane's room pale and gloomy, stating that he had found it all out and that it was as he thought. The fire was likely the source of the "peculiar and lugubrious" sound that Jane heard, as it would have been making crackling and popping noises as it burned.

edge.target: The 'marrow-freezing' incident that occurred on the night in question was hearing a demoniac laugh behind the keyhole of Jane's chamber door. This incident caused her to be unable to sleep because it was a scary and unsettling experience that made her heart beat anxiously and broke her inward tranquility. She tried to sleep again but couldn't due to her fear and the silence that composed her nerves. The sound of the clock striking two and the sensation of her chamber-door being touched only added to her fear, making it impossible for her to sleep.

edge.target:
The man claims he is not a general philanthropist because he does not like the society of children and old women, and he asserts that he bears a conscience, pointing to the prominent bones on his forehead which are said to indicate that faculty. He mentions that he used to be a feeling fellow when he was younger, partial to the unfledged, unfostered, and unlucky. However, he suggests that his personality has changed due to the harsh blows of fortune.
The man's description of his past feelings of tenderness towards the unfortunate reveals that he used to have a kind heart and cared for those who were less fortunate. However, his experiences and circumstances have made him moody, harsh, and severe to others, although the narrator believes that he still has excellent materials within him.
In summary, the man's claim of not being a general philanthropist is due to his personal preferences and past experiences that have shaped his personality. Despite his intellectual appearance, his actions and behavior suggest that he is not particularly inclined towards philanthropy.

edge.source:
Rochester _is_ peculiar--he seems to forget that he pays me 30 pounds per annum for receiving his orders.
"The smile is very well," said he, catching instantly the passing expression; "but speak too."
"I was thinking, sir, that very few masters would trouble themselves to inquire whether or not their paid subordinates were piqued and hurt by their orders."
"Paid subordinates! What! you are my paid subordinate, are you? Oh yes, I had forgotten the salary! Well then, on that mercenary ground, will you agree to let me hector a little?"
"No, sir, not on that ground; but, on the ground that you did forget it, and that you care whether or not a dependent is comfortable in his dependency, I agree heartily."
"And will you consent to dispense with a great many conventional forms and phrases, without thinking that the omission arises from insolence?"
"I am sure, sir, I should never mistake informality for insolence: one I rather like, the other nothing free-born would submit to, even for a salary."

It is also possible that he is so caught up in his own thoughts and concerns that he forgets about the practical arrangements of their working relationship.
Another possibility is that Mr. Rochester sees Jane as more than just a subordinate, and he may value her opinions and companionship beyond what she is being paid to provide. Overall, it is difficult to say for certain why Mr. Rochester is overlooking the fact that Jane is being paid to follow his orders. The narrative does not provide enough information to make a definitive judgment on this point.

edge.target: The character, Mr. Rochester, is expressing his resolution to change his ways and improve himself, with the goal of having better associates and pursuits in the future. While it is not possible to ensure this outcome completely, he believes that by making a concerted effort to correct his thoughts and actions, he will naturally attract better influences and opportunities into his life. This is based on the idea that our surroundings and relationships are often a reflection of our own character and choices. By striving to become a better person and making more positive choices, he hopes to create new and stainless stores of recollections and lead a more fulfilling life.

edge.target: It is not possible to ensure with absolute certainty that one's resolution to correct thoughts and actions will result in becoming what one approves of and improving associates and pursuits. However, the general idea is that by making a concerted effort to improve oneself, one is likely to attract better influences and opportunities into their life. This is based on the principle that our surroundings and relationships are often a reflection of our own character and choices. By striving to become a better person and making more positive choices, it is more likely that better associates and pursuits will follow. However, this is not a guarantee, and there is always the possibility of setbacks or unforeseen circumstances. Nonetheless, the important thing is to make a sincere effort and remain committed to self-improvement.

edge.source: I steadily reviewed the tale Mr. Rochester had told me. As he had said, there was probably nothing at all extraordinary in the substance of the narrative itself: a wealthy Englishman's passion for a French dancer, and her treachery to him, were every-day matters enough, no doubt, in society; but there was something decidedly strange in the paroxysm of emotion which had suddenly seized him when he was in the act of expressing the present contentment of his mood, and his newly revived pleasure in the old hall and its environs. I meditated wonderingly on this incident; but gradually quitting it, as I found it for the present inexplicable, I turned to the consideration of my master's manner to myself. The confidence he had thought fit to repose in me seemed a tribute to my discretion: I regarded and accepted it as such. His deportment had now for some weeks been more uniform towards me than at the first. I never seemed in his way; he did not take fits of chilling hauteur: when he met me unexpectedly, the encounter seemed welcome; he had always a word
edge.target: The peculiar and lugubrious sound heard above the narrator's head is never explicitly identified, but it is initially attributed to Pilot, Mr. Rochester's dog, who is known to wander into the hallway from the kitchen. The sound causes fear and anxiety in the narrator because it is hushed, irregular, and seems to be coming from the dark gallery outside her door. This mysterious sound, combined with the late hour and the darkness, leads to a feeling of unease and suspicion that it might be something or someone unfamiliar. The narrator's active imagination and the gloomy atmosphere of the old house also contribute to her fear and anxiety.

edge.target: Mr. Rochester expresses gratitude towards Jane because she has "saved his life" by preventing him from going to the top of the tower in a state of excitement, which could have resulted in a fatal accident. He is surprised that she is leaving without shaking his hand because, despite asking her to leave, he also wants a gesture of goodwill and acknowledgment for her actions. He feels a strong connection to Jane and wants to maintain a connection before she departs.

should never mistake informality for insolence: one I rather like, the other nothing free-born would submit to, even for a salary."
"Humbug! Most things free-born will submit to anything for a salary; therefore, keep to yourself, and don't venture on generalities of which you are intensely ignorant. However, I mentally shake hands with you for your answer, despite its inaccuracy; and as much for the manner in which it was said, as for the substance of the speech; the manner was frank and sincere; one does not often see such a manner: no, on the contrary, affectation, or coldness, or stupid, coarse-minded misapprehension of one's meaning are the usual rewards of candour. Not three in three thousand raw school-girl-governesses would have answered me as you have just done. But I don't mean to flatter you: if you are cast in a different mould to the majority, it is no merit of yours: Nature did it. And then, after all, I go too fast in my conclusions: for what I yet know, you

In the narrative, Jane Eyre quickly takes action to save Mr. Rochester and his bed from burning by using water from the basin, ewer, and her own water-jug. Here's the step-by-step process of what she does:
1. Wakes up to the sight of flames around Mr. Rochester's bed, caused by the curtains being on fire. 2. Realizes that Mr. Rochester is in a deep sleep and the smoke has stupefied him, so she cannot rely on him to wake up and help. 3. Shouts "Wake! wake!" and shakes Mr. Rochester, but he only murmurs and turns, so she knows she needs to take matters into her own hands. 4. Rushes to Mr. Rochester's basin and ewer, which are both filled with water. She is fortunate that one is wide and the other is deep, allowing her to scoop up a significant amount of water. 5. Deluges the bed and its occupant (Mr. Rochester) with the water from the basin and ewer. 6. Quickly goes back to her own room and brings her own water-jug, using it to baptize the couch (the bed) again, ensuring that she extinguishes all the flames. 7. The hiss of the quenched element, the breakage of a pitcher she flung away after emptying it, and the splash of the shower-bath she had liberally bestowed rouse Mr. Rochester from his sleep.
Thanks to Jane Eyre's quick thinking and actions, she successfully saves Mr. Rochester and his bed from burning.
edge.target:
a cloud from thence. I thought no more of Mrs. Fairfax; I thought no more of Grace Poole, or the laugh: in an instant, I was within the chamber. Tongues of flame darted round the bed: the curtains were on fire. In the midst of blaze and vapour, Mr. Rochester lay stretched motionless, in deep sleep.
"Wake! wake!" I cried. I shook him, but he only murmured and turned: the smoke had stupefied him. Not a moment could be lost: the very sheets were kindling, I rushed to his basin and ewer; fortunately, one was wide and the other deep, and both were filled with water. I heaved them up, deluged the bed and its occupant, flew back to my own room, brought my own water-jug, baptized the couch afresh, and, by God's aid, succeeded in extinguishing the flames which were devouring it.

edge.target:
hiss of the quenched element, the breakage of a pitcher which I flung from my hand when I had emptied it, and, above all, the splash of the shower-bath I had liberally bestowed, roused Mr. Rochester at last. Though it was now dark, I knew he was awake; because I heard him fulminating strange anathemas at finding himself lying in a pool of water.
"Is there a flood?" he cried.
"No, sir," I answered; "but there has been a fire: get up, do; you are quenched now; I will fetch you a candle."
"In the name of all the elves in Christendom, is that Jane Eyre?" he demanded. "What have you done with me, witch, sorceress? Who is in the room besides you? Have you plotted to drown me?"

edge.source:
a cloud from thence. I thought no more of Mrs. Fairfax; I thought no more of Grace Poole, or the laugh: in an instant, I was within the chamber. Tongues of flame darted round the bed: the curtains were on fire. In the midst of blaze and vapour, Mr. Rochester lay stretched motionless, in deep sleep.
"Wake! wake!" I cried. I shook him, but he only murmured and turned: the smoke had stupefied him. Not a moment could be lost: the very sheets were kindling, I rushed to his basin and ewer; fortunately, one was wide and the other deep, and both were filled with water. I heaved them up, deluged the bed and its occupant, flew back to my own room, brought my own water-jug, baptized the couch afresh, and, by God's aid, succeeded in extinguishing the flames which were devouring it.

The sound of the clock striking two and the sensation of her chamber-door being touched only added to her fear, making it impossible for her to sleep.

In the narrative, Mr. Rochester is asking Jane Eyre if she thinks he is handsome and Jane responds honestly by saying "No, sir." This response is not meant as an insult, but rather as a reflection of her personal taste and her focus on his inner qualities. However, the question you have posed refers to a different part of the narrative, where Jane is reflecting on Mr. Rochester's behavior towards her and how he seems to forget that she receives a salary of 30 pounds per annum to follow his orders.
There could be several reasons why Mr. Rochester might be overlooking this fact. One possibility is that he is so used to being in a position of power and authority that he does not even consider the fact that Jane is being paid for her services. It is also possible that he is so caught up in his own thoughts and concerns that he forgets about the practical arrangements of their working relationship.
Another possibility is that Mr. Rochester sees Jane as more than just a subordinate, and he may value her opinions and companionship beyond what she is being paid to provide. This could be why he is willing to confide in her and share personal information with her, even though she is technically an employee.
Overall, it is difficult to say for certain why Mr. Rochester is overlooking the fact that Jane is being paid to follow his orders. The narrative does not provide enough information to make a definitive judgment on this point.

The speaker's 'cherished preserver' in this narrative is Mr. Rochester, who is described as speaking in an enigmatical language that bewilders Jane Eyre. He talks to her about a tempting suggestion that he perceives as a divine presence and a positive force that has transformed his heart from a place of death and decay to a place of reverence and devotion.
During their late-night encounter, Mr. Rochester's behavior is somewhat cryptic and difficult to understand. He speaks in riddles and uses language that Jane finds confusing. He also accuses her of being afraid of him, which she denies. Despite his confusing behavior, Jane remains calm and composed, and she handles the situation with grace and dignity.
The speaker, who is Jane in this context, responds to Mr. Rochester's actions by remaining respectful and polite, even though she does not understand what he is talking about. She tries to make sense of his words, but ultimately decides to end the conversation, stating that it is useless to continue. She then excuses herself to put Adele to bed, showing that she is still focused on her duties as a governess.
Overall, Jane's emotional state during this encounter is one of bewilderment and uncertainty. She is unsure of what Mr. Rochester is trying to convey, and she feels a sense of insecurity and ignorance. However, she remains calm and composed, and she responds to his actions with respect and dignity.

The speaker advises resisting temptation and choosing the path of reformation, as giving in to temptation may lead to degeneration and further sin. The speaker warns of the potential misery and bitterness that can result from yielding to temptation, and describes remorse as the "poison of life." However, the speaker expresses doubt about the possibility of reformation in their own situation, given their current circumstances. They acknowledge their past mistakes and faults, and imply that they have a history that is not entirely virtuous. The speaker also warns against underestimating the consequences of giving in to temptation, cautioning that the person tempted may not fully understand the potential outcomes.
The speaker believes that they have experienced a positive transformation after receiving a tempting suggestion that they perceive to be a "disguised deity" or divine presence. They describe their heart as having been a "charnel" before, but becoming a "shrine" after receiving the tempting suggestion. The speaker sees the tempting suggestion as a positive force that has done them good and has the potential to continue to do so.
Regarding remorse, the speaker believes that it is not the cure for error, but reformation may be. They express regret for not having stood firm in the face of adversity and for degenerating when fate wronged them. The speaker wishes they had remained cool and not turned desperate, but acknowledges that they did not have the wisdom to do so at the time. They advise distrusting any temptation that may arise, but also question the ability to distinguish between a true angel and a fallen seraph of the abyss or a guide and a seducer.

edge.target:
After being saved by her "cherished preserver," who is Mr. Rochester, the speaker, Jane Eyre, experiences a range of emotions. She feels a "strange energy" in his voice and a "strange fire" in his look, indicating a powerful and intense emotional connection to him. Despite being cold, she initially stays because she is glad to have been awake to experience his presence. When she tries to leave, Mr. Rochester still retains her hand and she has to use the ruse of thinking she hears Mrs. Fairfax move to free herself.
Once she is back in her room, Jane is unable to sleep and is instead "tossed on a buoyant but unquiet sea, where billows of trouble rolled under surges of joy." This suggests that she is experiencing a mix of positive and negative emotions, possibly including excitement, confusion, and perhaps fear or unease due to the intensity of her feelings for Mr. Rochester. Overall, Jane's emotional state is one of turmoil and uncertainty, as she tries to make sense of the intense emotions she is experiencing.

edge.target:
peculiar and lugubrious, which sounded, I thought, just above me. I wished I had kept my candle burning: the night was drearily dark; my spirits were depressed. I rose and sat up in bed, listening. The sound was hushed.
I tried again to sleep; but my heart beat anxiously: my inward tranquillity was broken. The clock, far down in the hall, struck two. Just then it seemed my chamber-door was touched; as if fingers had swept the panels in groping a way along the dark gallery outside. I said, "Who is there?" Nothing answered. I was chilled with fear.
All at once I remembered that it might be Pilot, who, when the kitchen- door chanced to be left open, not unfrequently found his way up to the threshold of Mr. Rochester's chamber: I had seen him lying there myself in the mornings. The idea calmed me somewhat: I lay down. Silence composes the nerves; and as an unbroken hush now reigned again through the whole house, I began to feel the return of slumber.

edge.source:
In the narrative, Jane Eyre saves Mr. Rochester and his bed from burning by quickly taking action when she sees the flames caused by the curtains being on fire. Here's a step-by-step breakdown of what she does:
1. She notices that Mr. Rochester is in a deep sleep and the smoke has stupefied him, so she cannot rely on him to wake up and help. 2. She takes immediate action by using water from the basin and ewer in Mr. Rochester's room to deluge the bed and its occupant. 3. She then brings her own water-jug from her room to baptize the couch again, ensuring that she extinguishes all the flames. 4. The hissing sound of the quenched element, the breakage of a pitcher she flung away after emptying it, and the splash of the water she had liberally bestowed rouse Mr. Rochester from his sleep.
By quickly and efficiently using the water sources available to her, Jane Eyre successfully saves Mr. Rochester and his bed from a potentially dangerous fire.
edge.target:
be as still as a mouse. I must pay a visit to the second storey. Don't move, remember, or call any one."
He went: I watched the light withdraw. He passed up the gallery very softly, unclosed the staircase door with as little noise as possible, shut it after him, and the last ray vanished. I was left in total darkness. I listened for some noise, but heard nothing. A very long time elapsed. I grew weary: it was cold, in spite of the cloak; and then I did not see the use of staying, as I was not to rouse the house. I was on the point of risking Mr. Rochester's displeasure by disobeying his orders, when the light once more gleamed dimly on the gallery wall, and I heard his unshod feet tread the matting. "I hope it is he," thought I, "and not something worse."
He re-entered, pale and very gloomy. "I have found it all out," said he, setting his candle down on the washstand; "it is as I thought."

On recognising him, the fang of the snake Jealousy was instantly broken; because at the same moment my love for Celine sank under an extinguisher. A woman who could betray me for such a rival was not worth contending for; she deserved only scorn; less, however, than I, who had been her dupe.
"They began to talk; their conversation eased me completely: frivolous, mercenary, heartless, and senseless, it was rather calculated to weary than enrage a listener. Neither of them possessed energy or wit to belabour me soundly, but they insulted me as coarsely as they could in their little way: especially Celine, who even waxed rather brilliant on my personal defects--deformities she termed them. Now it had been her custom to launch out into fervent admiration

Here ensued a pause, filled up by the producing and lighting of a cigar; having placed it to his lips and breathed a trail of Havannah incense on the freezing and sunless air, he went on--
"I liked bonbons too in those days, Miss Eyre, and I was _croquant_--(overlook the barbarism)--_croquant_ chocolate comfits, and smoking alternately, watching meantime the equipages that rolled along the fashionable streets towards the neighbouring opera-house, when in an elegant close carriage drawn by a beautiful pair of English horses, and distinctly seen in the brilliant city-night, I recognised the 'voiture' I had given Celine. She was returning: of course my heart thumped with impatience against the iron rails I leant upon. "I remained in the balcony. 'They will come to her boudoir, no doubt,' thought I: 'let me prepare an ambush.' So putting my hand in through the open window, I drew the curtain over it, leaving only an opening through which I could take observations; then I closed the casement, all but a chink just wide enough to furnish an outlet to lovers' whispered vows: then I stole back to my chair; and as I resumed it the pair came in. My eye was quickly at the aperture. Celine's chamber-maid entered, lit a lamp, left it on the table, and withdrew. The couple were thus revealed to me clearly: both removed their cloaks, and there was 'the Varens,' shining in satin and jewels,--my gifts of course,--and there was her companion in an officer's uniform; and I knew him for a young roue of a vicomte--a brainless and vicious youth whom I had sometimes met in society, and had

edge.target:
a French opera-dancer, Celine Varens, towards whom he had once cherished what he called a "_grande passion_." This passion Celine had professed to return with even superior ardour. He thought himself her idol, ugly as he was: he believed, as he said, that she preferred his "_taille d'athlete_" to the elegance of the Apollo Belvidere.
"And, Miss Eyre, so much was I flattered by this preference of the Gallic sylph for her British gnome, that I installed her in an hotel; gave her a complete establishment of servants, a carriage, cashmeres, diamonds, dentelles, &c. In short, I began the process of ruining myself in the received style, like any other spoony. I had not, it seems, the originality to chalk out a new road to shame and destruction, but trode the old track with stupid exactness not to deviate an inch from the beaten centre. I had--as I deserved to have--the fate of all other spoonies.

Adele here ran before him with her shuttlecock. "Away!" he cried harshly; "keep at a distance, child; or go in to Sophie!" Continuing then to pursue his walk in silence, I ventured to recall him to the point whence he had abruptly diverged--
"Did you leave the balcony, sir," I asked, "when Mdlle. Varens entered?"
I almost expected a rebuff for this hardly well-timed question, but, on the contrary, waking out of his scowling abstraction, he turned his eyes towards me, and the shade seemed to clear off his brow. "Oh, I had forgotten Celine! Well, to resume. When I saw my charmer thus come in accompanied by a cavalier, I seemed to hear a hiss, and the green snake of jealousy, rising on undulating coils from the moonlit balcony, glided within my waistcoat, and ate its way in two minutes to my heart's core. edge.source:
knew him for a young roue of a vicomte--a brainless and vicious youth whom I had sometimes met in society, and had never thought of hating because I despised him so absolutely. On recognising him, the fang of the snake Jealousy was instantly broken; because at the same moment my love for Celine sank under an extinguisher. A woman who could betray me for such a rival was not worth contending for; she deserved only scorn; less, however, than I, who had been her dupe.
"They began to talk; their conversation eased me completely: frivolous, mercenary, heartless, and senseless, it was rather calculated to weary than enrage a listener. A card of mine lay on the table; this being perceived, brought my name under discussion. Neither of them possessed energy or wit to belabour me soundly, but they insulted me as coarsely as they could in their little way: especially Celine, who even waxed rather brilliant on my personal defects--deformities she termed them. Now it had been her custom to launch out into fervent admiration

the better; for while I cannot blight you, you may refresh me." After this digression he proceeded--
"I remained in the balcony. 'They will come to her boudoir, no doubt,' thought I: 'let me prepare an ambush.' So putting my hand in through the open window, I drew the curtain over it, leaving only an opening through which I could take observations; then I closed the casement, all but a chink just wide enough to furnish an outlet to lovers' whispered vows: then I stole back to my chair; and as I resumed it the pair came in. My eye was quickly at the aperture. Celine's chamber-maid entered, lit a lamp, left it on the table, and withdrew. The couple were thus revealed to me clearly: both removed their cloaks, and there was 'the Varens,' shining in satin and jewels,--my gifts of course,--and there was her companion in an officer's uniform; and I knew him for a young roue of a vicomte--a brainless and vicious youth whom I had sometimes met in society, and had

edge.source:
a French opera-dancer, Celine Varens, towards whom he had once cherished what he called a "_grande passion_." This passion Celine had professed to return with even superior ardour. He thought himself her idol, ugly as he was: he believed, as he said, that she preferred his "_taille d'athlete_" to the elegance of the Apollo Belvidere.
"And, Miss Eyre, so much was I flattered by this preference of the Gallic sylph for her British gnome, that I installed her in an hotel; gave her a complete establishment of servants, a carriage, cashmeres, diamonds, dentelles, &c. In short, I began the process of ruining myself in the received style, like any other spoony. I had not, it seems, the originality to chalk out a new road to shame and destruction, but trode the old track with stupid exactness not to deviate an inch from the beaten centre. I had--as I deserved to have--the fate of all other spoonies.

others count as iron and brass, I will esteem but straw and rotten wood."
Adele here ran before him with her shuttlecock. "Away!" he cried harshly; "keep at a distance, child; or go in to Sophie!" Continuing then to pursue his walk in silence, I ventured to recall him to the point whence he had abruptly diverged--
"Did you leave the balcony, sir," I asked, "when Mdlle. Varens entered?"
I almost expected a rebuff for this hardly well-timed question, but, on the contrary, waking out of his scowling abstraction, he turned his eyes towards me, and the shade seemed to clear off his brow. "Oh, I had forgotten Celine! Well, to resume. When I saw my charmer thus come in accompanied by a cavalier, I seemed to hear a hiss, and the green snake of jealousy, rising on undulating coils from the moonlit balcony, glided within my waistcoat, and ate its way in two minutes to my heart's core. Strange!" he exclaimed, suddenly starting again from the

The speaker believes that they have experienced a positive transformation after receiving what they perceive to be a "disguised deity" or divine presence in the form of a tempting suggestion. They describe their heart as having been a "charnel" before, which is a term used to describe a place where bodies are buried or a chamber for the dead. This suggests that the speaker saw their heart as a place of death and decay.
However, after receiving the tempting suggestion, the speaker describes their heart as becoming a "shrine," which is a place where a deity is worshipped or honored. This suggests that the speaker now sees their heart as a place of reverence and devotion, having been transformed by the divine presence they perceive in the tempting suggestion.
The speaker describes the tempting suggestion as "very genial, very soothing," and believes it to be an "inspiration rather than a temptation." They see it as a positive force that has done them good and has the potential to continue to do so.
Overall, the speaker believes that they have experienced a transformation from a state of death and decay to a state of reverence and devotion as a result of receiving the tempting suggestion they perceive to be a divine presence.

The speaker's 'cherished preserver' in this narrative is Mr. Rochester, who is described as speaking in an enigmatical language that bewilders Jane Eyre. He talks to her about a tempting suggestion that he perceives as a divine presence and a positive force that has transformed his heart from a place of death and decay to a place of reverence and devotion.
During their late-night encounter, Mr. Rochester's behavior is somewhat cryptic and difficult to understand. He speaks in riddles and uses language that Jane finds confusing. He also accuses her of being afraid of him, which she denies. Despite his confusing behavior, Jane remains calm and composed, and she handles the situation with grace and dignity.
The speaker, who is Jane in this context, responds to Mr. Rochester's actions by remaining respectful and polite, even though she does not understand what he is talking about. She tries to make sense of his words, but ultimately decides to end the conversation, stating that it is useless to continue. She then excuses herself to put Adele to bed, showing that she is still focused on her duties as a governess.
Overall, Jane's emotional state during this encounter is one of bewilderment and uncertainty. She is unsure of what Mr. Rochester is trying to convey, and she feels a sense of insecurity and ignorance. However, she remains calm and composed, and she responds to his actions with respect and dignity.

After being saved by her "cherished preserver," who is Mr. Rochester, the speaker, Jane Eyre, experiences a range of emotions. She feels a "strange energy" in his voice and a "strange fire" in his look, indicating a powerful and intense emotional connection to him. Despite being cold, she initially stays because she is glad to have been awake to experience his presence. When she tries to leave, Mr. Rochester still retains her hand and she has to use the ruse of thinking she hears Mrs. Fairfax move to free herself.
Once she is back in her room, Jane is unable to sleep and is instead "tossed on a buoyant but unquiet sea, where billows of trouble rolled under surges of joy." This suggests that she is experiencing a mix of positive and negative emotions, possibly including excitement, confusion, and perhaps fear or unease due to the intensity of her feelings for Mr. Rochester. Overall, Jane's emotional state is one of turmoil and uncertainty, as she tries to make sense of the intense emotions she is experiencing.

edge.target:
deviate an inch from the beaten centre. I had--as I deserved to have--the fate of all other spoonies. Happening to call one evening when Celine did not expect me, I found her out; but it was a warm night, and I was tired with strolling through Paris, so I sat down in her boudoir; happy to breathe the air consecrated so lately by her presence. No,--I exaggerate; I never thought there was any consecrating virtue about her: it was rather a sort of pastille perfume she had left; a scent of musk and amber, than an odour of sanctity. I was just beginning to stifle with the fumes of conservatory flowers and sprinkled essences, when I bethought myself to open the window and step out on to the balcony. It was moonlight and gaslight besides, and very still and serene. The balcony was furnished with a chair or two; I sat down, and took out a cigar,--I will take one now, if you will excuse me."

aut que je l'essaie!' cried she, 'et a l'instant meme!' and she rushed out of the room. However, my tenderest feelings are about to receive a shock: such is my presentiment; stay now, to see whether it will be realised."

"Est-ce que ma robe va bien?" cried she, bounding forwards; "et mes souliers? et mes bas? Tenez, je crois que je vais danser!"
And spreading out her dress, she chasseed across the room till, having reached Mr. Rochester, she wheeled lightly round before him on tip-toe, then dropped on one knee at his feet, exclaiming--
"Monsieur, je vous remercie mille fois de votre bonte;" then rising, she added, "C'est comme cela que maman faisait, n'est-ce pas, monsieur?"
"Pre-cise-ly!" was the answer; "and, 'comme cela,' she charmed my English gold out of my British breeches' pocket. I have been green, too, Miss Eyre,--ay, grass green: not a more vernal tint freshens you now than once freshened me. My Spring is gone, however, but it has left me that French floweret on my hands,

edge.source:
When Mlle. Varens, Mr. Rochester's former lover, entered the balcony with a cavalier, Mr. Rochester's mood dramatically changed from calm to jealousy. He describes the feeling as a green snake of jealousy that glided within his waistcoat and ate its way to his heart's core. This metaphor suggests the intensity of the emotion and how it quickly consumed him.
However, his jealousy was short-lived. When he recognized the cavalier as a young, brainless, and vicious vicomte, his love for Mlle. Varens sank, and his jealousy disappeared. He described her as not worth contending for and deserving only scorn, less for herself than for making him her dupe.
So, in summary, Mr. Rochester's mood changed from calm to intense jealousy when Mlle. Varens entered with a cavalier, but then his mood shifted to scorn and relief when he recognized the cavalier and lost interest in Mlle. Varens.

aut que je l'essaie!' cried she, 'et a l'instant meme!' and she rushed out of the room. However, my tenderest feelings are about to receive a shock: such is my presentiment; stay now, to see whether it will be realised."
Ere long, Adele's little foot was heard tripping across the hall. She entered, transformed as her guardian had predicted. edge.source: In the narrative, the speaker, Jane Eyre, is asked by Mr. Rochester if she thinks he is handsome. Jane responds honestly and says "No, sir." This response is not meant as an insult, but rather as a reflection of her personal taste and her focus on his inner qualities. She goes on to describe him as having "great, dark eyes, and very fine eyes, too" and notes that there is "a certain change in their depths sometimes, which, if it was not softness, reminded you, at least, of that feeling." These descriptions suggest that while Jane may not find Mr. Rochester traditionally handsome, she sees beauty in his eyes and finds him intriguing. Later in the narrative, Jane also reflects on Mr. Rochester's kindness to her and her belief that he has "excellent materials" within him, despite his moodiness and past faults. All of these factors suggest that Jane's initial response is not meant as a dismissal of Mr. Rochester's appearance, but rather as a nuanced and thoughtful assessment of his character.

"You examine me, Miss Eyre," said he: "do you think me handsome?"
I should, if I had deliberated, have replied to this question by something conventionally vague and polite; but the answer somehow slipped from my tongue before I was aware--"No, sir."

edge.target:
After being saved by her "cherished preserver," who is Mr. Rochester, the speaker, Jane Eyre, experiences a range of emotions. She feels a "strange energy" in his voice and a "strange fire" in his look, indicating a powerful and intense emotional connection to him. Despite being cold, she initially stays because she is glad to have been awake to experience his presence. When she tries to leave, Mr. Rochester still retains her hand and she has to use the ruse of thinking she hears Mrs. Fairfax move to free herself.
Once she is back in her room, Jane is unable to sleep and is instead "tossed on a buoyant but unquiet sea, where billows of trouble rolled under surges of joy." This suggests that she is experiencing a mix of positive and negative emotions, possibly including excitement, confusion, and perhaps fear or unease due to the intensity of her feelings for Mr. Rochester. Overall, Jane's emotional state is one of turmoil and uncertainty, as she tries to make sense of the intense emotions she is experiencing.

Despite Mr. Rochester's continued faults and harshness towards others, Jane's perspective and feelings towards him remain positive due to their genuine and meaningful interactions. He is surprised that she is leaving without shaking his hand because, despite asking her to leave, he also wants a gesture of goodwill and acknowledgment for her actions. He feels a strong connection to Jane and wants to maintain a connection before she departs.

The man claims he is not a general philanthropist because he does not like the society of children and old women, and he asserts that he bears a conscience, pointing to the prominent bones on his forehead which are said to indicate that faculty. He mentions that he used to be a feeling fellow when he was younger, partial to the unfledged, unfostered, and unlucky. However, he suggests that his personality has changed due to the harsh blows of fortune.
The man's description of his past feelings of tenderness towards the unfortunate reveals that he used to have a kind heart and cared for those who were less fortunate. However, his experiences and circumstances have made him moody, harsh, and severe to others, although the narrator believes that he still has excellent materials within him.
In summary, the man's claim of not being a general philanthropist is due to his personal preferences and past experiences that have shaped his personality. Despite his intellectual appearance, his actions and behavior suggest that he is not particularly inclined towards philanthropy.

many nations, and roamed over half the globe, while you have lived quietly with one set of people in one house?"
"Do as you please, sir."
"That is no answer; or rather it is a very irritating, because a very evasive one. Reply clearly."
"I don't think, sir, you have a right to command me, merely because you are older than I, or because you have seen more of the world than I have; your claim to superiority depends on the use you have made of your time and experience."
"Humph! Promptly spoken. But I won't allow that, seeing that it would never suit my case, as I have made an indifferent, not to say a bad, use of both advantages. Leaving superiority out of the question, then, you must still agree to receive my orders now and then, without being piqued or hurt by the tone of command. Will you?"
I smiled: I thought to myself Mr. Rochester _is_ peculiar--he seems to forget that he pays me 30 pounds per annum for receiving his orders.

many nations, and roamed over half the globe, while you have lived quietly with one set of people in one house?"
"Do as you please, sir."
"That is no answer; or rather it is a very irritating, because a very evasive one. Reply clearly."
"I don't think, sir, you have a right to command me, merely because you are older than I, or because you have seen more of the world than I have; your claim to superiority depends on the use you have made of your time and experience."
"Humph! Promptly spoken. But I won't allow that, seeing that it would never suit my case, as I have made an indifferent, not to say a bad, use of both advantages. Leaving superiority out of the question, then, you must still agree to receive my orders now and then, without being piqued or hurt by the tone of command. Will you?"
I smiled: I thought to myself Mr. Rochester _is_ peculiar--he seems to forget that he pays me 30 pounds per annum for receiving his orders.

edge.source: The character, Mr. Rochester, is expressing his resolution to change his ways and improve himself, with the goal of having better associates and pursuits in the future. While it is not possible to ensure this outcome completely, he believes that by making a concerted effort to correct his thoughts and actions, he will naturally attract better influences and opportunities into his life. This is based on the idea that our surroundings and relationships are often a reflection of our own character and choices. By striving to become a better person and making more positive choices, he hopes to create new and stainless stores of recollections and lead a more fulfilling life.
edge.target:
all: I cannot keep up the conversation, because it has got out of my depth. Only one thing, I know: you said you were not as good as you should like to be, and that you regretted your own imperfection;--one thing I can comprehend: you intimated that to have a sullied memory was a perpetual bane. It seems to me, that if you tried hard, you would in time find it possible to become what you yourself would approve; and that if from this day you began with resolution to correct your thoughts and actions, you would in a few years have laid up a new and stainless store of recollections, to which you might revert with pleasure."
"Justly thought; rightly said, Miss Eyre; and, at this moment, I am paving hell with energy."
"Sir?"
"I am laying down good intentions, which I believe durable as flint. Certainly, my associates and pursuits shall be other than they have been."
"And better?"
"And better--so much better as pure ore is than foul dross. You seem to doubt me

edge.target: Based on the narrator's description of a woman's arrival at a hotel, it can be inferred that Miss Eyre has not yet experienced feelings of love and jealousy. The narrator, Mr. Rochester, notes that Miss Eyre has not felt love and therefore has not experienced jealousy either. He states that her soul "sleeps" and has not undergone the "shock" that would awaken such emotions. Miss Eyre herself acknowledges that she has not felt these emotions when she asks Mr. Rochester how he knows that she has not experienced love or jealousy.

edge.source: The 'marrow-freezing' incident that occurred on the night in question was hearing a demoniac laugh behind the keyhole of Jane's chamber door. This incident caused her to be unable to sleep because it was a scary and unsettling experience that made her heart beat anxiously and broke her inward tranquility. She tried to sleep again but couldn't due to her fear and the silence that composed her nerves. The sound of the clock striking two and the sensation of her chamber-door being touched only added to her fear, making it impossible for her to sleep.
edge.target:
After being saved by her "cherished preserver," who is Mr. Rochester, the speaker, Jane Eyre, experiences a range of emotions. She feels a "strange energy" in his voice and a "strange fire" in his look, indicating a powerful and intense emotional connection to him. Despite being cold, she initially stays because she is glad to have been awake to experience his presence. When she tries to leave, Mr. Rochester still retains her hand and she has to use the ruse of thinking she hears Mrs. Fairfax move to free herself.
Once she is back in her room, Jane is unable to sleep and is instead "tossed on a buoyant but unquiet sea, where billows of trouble rolled under surges of joy." This suggests that she is experiencing a mix of positive and negative emotions, possibly including excitement, confusion, and perhaps fear or unease due to the intensity of her feelings for Mr. Rochester. Overall, Jane's emotional state is one of turmoil and uncertainty, as she tries to make sense of the intense emotions she is experiencing.

He is surprised that she is leaving without shaking his hand because, despite asking her to leave, he also wants a gesture of goodwill and acknowledgment for her actions. He feels a strong connection to Jane and wants to maintain a connection before she departs.

cruciating death! and you walk past me as if we were mutual strangers! At least shake hands."
He held out his hand; I gave him mine: he took it first in one, them in both his own.
"You have saved my life: I have a pleasure in owing you so immense a debt. I cannot say more. Nothing else that has being would have been tolerable to me in the character of creditor for such an obligation: but you: it is different;--I feel your benefits no burden, Jane."
He paused; gazed at me: words almost visible trembled on his lips,--but his voice was checked.
"Good-night again, sir. There is no debt, benefit, burden, obligation, in the case."
"I knew," he continued, "you would do me good in some way, at some time;--I saw it in your eyes when I first beheld you: their expression and smile did not"--(again he stopped)--"did not" (he proceeded hastily) "strike delight to my very inmost heart so for nothing. People talk of natural sympath

edge.target:
For several subsequent days I saw little of Mr. Rochester. In the mornings he seemed much engaged with business, and, in the afternoon, gentlemen from Millcote or the neighbourhood called, and sometimes stayed to dine with him. When his sprain was well enough to admit of horse exercise, he rode out a good deal; probably to return these visits, as he generally did not come back till late at night.
During this interval, even Adele was seldom sent for to his presence, and all my acquaintance with him was confined to an occasional rencontre in the hall, on the stairs, or in the gallery, when he would sometimes pass me haughtily and coldly, just acknowledging my presence by a distant nod or a cool glance, and sometimes bow and smile with gentlemanlike affability. His changes of mood did not offend me, because I saw that I had nothing to do with their alternation; the ebb and flow depended on causes quite disconnected with me.
One day he had had company to dinner, and had sent for my portfolio; in order, doubtless, to exhibit its contents: the gentlemen

The speaker advises resisting temptation and choosing the path of reformation, as giving in to temptation may lead to degeneration and further sin. They warn of the potential misery and bitterness that can result from yielding to temptation, and describe remorse as the "poison of life." However, the speaker expresses doubt about the possibility of reformation in their own situation, given their current circumstances. They also caution that the person tempted may not fully understand the potential outcomes of giving in to temptation.
Regarding repentance, the speaker believes that it is not the cure for error, but reformation may be. They express regret for not having stood firm in the face of adversity and for degenerating when fate wronged them. The speaker wishes they had remained cool and not turned desperate, but acknowledges that they did not have the wisdom to do so at the time. They advise distrusting any temptation that may arise, but also question the ability to distinguish between a true angel and a fallen seraph of the abyss or a guide and a seducer.

The man claims he is not a general philanthropist because he does not like the society of children and old women, and he asserts that he bears a conscience, pointing to the prominent bones on his forehead which are said to indicate that faculty. He mentions that he used to be a feeling fellow when he was younger, partial to the unfledged, unfostered, and unlucky. However, he suggests that his personality has changed due to the harsh blows of fortune.
The man's description of his past feelings of tenderness towards the unfortunate reveals that he used to have a kind heart and cared for those who were less fortunate. However, his experiences and circumstances have made him moody, harsh, and severe to others, although the narrator believes that he still has excellent materials within him.
In summary, the man's claim of not being a general philanthropist is due to his personal preferences and past experiences that have shaped his personality. Despite his intellectual appearance, his actions and behavior suggest that he is not particularly inclined towards philanthropy.
edge.target:
the sable waves of hair which lay horizontally over his brow, and showed a solid enough mass of intellectual organs, but an abrupt deficiency where the suave sign of benevolence should have risen.
"Now, ma'am, am I a fool?"
"Far from it, sir. You would, perhaps, think me rude if I inquired in return whether you are a philanthropist?"
"There again! Another stick of the penknife, when she pretended to pat my head: and that is because I said I did not like the society of children and old women (low be it spoken!). No, young lady, I am not a general philanthropist; but I bear a conscience;" and he pointed to the prominences which are said to indicate that faculty, and which, fortunately for him, were sufficiently conspicuous; giving, indeed, a marked breadth to the upper part of his head: "and, besides, I once had a kind of rude tenderness of heart. When I was as old as you, I was a feeling fellow enough, partial to the unfledged, unfostered, and unlucky; but Fortune has knocked me

edge.source: The speaker is experiencing a transformation from a state of negativity and despair to a state of positivity and reverence after receiving what they perceive to be a "disguised deity" or divine presence in the form of a tempting suggestion. They describe their heart as a "charnel" before, which is a term used to describe a place where bodies are buried or a chamber for the dead. This suggests that the speaker saw their heart as a place of death and decay. However, after receiving the tempting suggestion, the speaker describes their heart as becoming a "shrine," which is a place where a deity is worshipped or honored. This suggests that the speaker now sees their heart as a place of reverence and devotion, having been transformed by the divine presence they perceive in the tempting suggestion. The speaker believes that the tempting suggestion is a positive force that has done them good and has the potential to continue to do so. They describe it as "very genial, very soothing," and believe it to be an "inspiration rather than a temptation."

The speaker advises resisting temptation and choosing the path of reformation, as giving in to temptation may lead to degeneration and further sin. They warn of the potential misery and bitterness that can result from yielding to temptation, and describe remorse as the "poison of life." However, the speaker expresses doubt about the possibility of reformation in their own situation, given their current circumstances. They also caution that the person tempted may not fully understand the potential outcomes of giving in to temptation.
Regarding repentance, the speaker believes that it is not the cure for error, but reformation may be. They express regret for not having stood firm in the face of adversity and for degenerating when fate wronged them. The speaker wishes they had remained cool and not turned desperate, but acknowledges that they did not have the wisdom to do so at the time. They advise distrusting any temptation that may arise, but also question the ability to distinguish between a true angel and a fallen seraph of the abyss or a guide and a seducer.
